thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Phuket.
distribution: India (Assam) SW China, through Myanmar (type), Laos, and south as far as SW Cambodia and east to Japan (Ryukyus).
ecology: Primary and secondary tropical rain forests, bamboo-thickets, riverbanks, swamps, sometimes on limestone; below 1,700 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phuket. See note below.
distribution: Indo-Malesia to Oceania. It is not clear where, if anywhere, this species occurs wild. It was evidently distributed widely in tropical Asia as a subsistence crop in prehistoric times and is now pantropical by introduction as an ornamental. For discussion of the very extensive synonomy see Hay, Wise, Blumea 35, 499–545. 1991, and Hay, Gard. Bull. Singapore 50(2): 221–334, 1998.
ecology: Roadside ditches, margins of wet fields, frequently cultivated as an ornamental in a number of selected forms; 0–500 m alt.

thailand: All over the country.
distribution: Widely distributed from Vietnam, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Java (type), Borneo and the Philippines.
ecology: A very common palm distributed in light-open habitats. It is found associated with mangroves where it forms tussocks. It thrives in light-open disturbed habitats such as ditches along roads and dikes separating rice paddies. Finally, it occurs behind the coastline in Peninsular Thailand in forests dominated by Melaleuca cajuputi forests.

ecology: Found primarily in wet evergreen forests often associated with limestone outcrops.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (type: Gibbons & Spanner s.n., holotype -BKF, isotype -K).
ecology: Restricted to limestone, often growing at the edge of precipices. Narrow endemic to a few mountain ranges near Chiang Mai. Today it only occurs on the highest ridges from 1,800–2,175 m but may have been much more common in the mountain forests at lower altitudes.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (type: Dransfield 2349, holotype -K).

distribution: Sri Lanka across SE Asia to Tropical Australia and the Solomon Islands in the East.
ecology: Restricted to mangrove. Early pollination studies concluded drosophilid flies to be the most likely pollinators (Essig 1973). However, recent investigations have revealed the putative importance of other functional groups of insects such as muscid flies, Apis bees,Trigona bees and nitidulid beetles in transferring pollen grains (Fong 1987; Eg Hoppe 2005).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Pui, Wang Tao, Doi Inthanon), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang, Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khriti); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP).
distribution: Widespread: SE Asia (Sri Lanka – type) to Australia, also S America where introduced.
ecology: In open or shaded moist places; in primary evergreen or seasonal montane forests; sandstone and granite bedrock, also on limestone; 600–1,600 m alt. Flowering and fruiting all year round.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Ang Khang, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Chiang Dao WS, Om Koi, Mai Muang Nao Arboretum), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phitsanulok (Phu Hin Rongkla); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khao Laem NP, Huai Bankao).
distribution: Widespread: N & S India (type), Sri Lanka, east to China, south-east through Indochina to Indonesia (the Lesser Sunda Islands), 0–2,000 m alt., not in wet localities. Also known from Africa (e.g. Ethiopia).
ecology: Common. In mixed hardwood and pine forests, lower montane pine-oak forests, slopes with scattered pine trees, open places in evergreen forests, hill evergreen forests, clearings on limestone; on sandstone, shale, or granite bedrock; 750–1,700 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–January.

ecology: Damp, (half)shaded places, from sea level to 1,200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Pha Hom Pok).
distribution: Nepal (type), N India to E Asia (Sakhalin, south through Japan, to Taiwan, the Philippines, and Papua New Guinea).
ecology: Small open spaces in evergreen forests at 2,000 m alt. Flowering: April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Luang NP, Doi Suthep, Chiang Dao WS, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Lon, Om Koi, Ban Mae Klang Luang, Hot), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phrae (Mae Krai), Tak (Umphang); Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Wong NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Pompee), Phetchaburi (Kaeng Kra Chan NP); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Pho Ta Luang Kaeo).
distribution: South China (no material seen), S Myanmar, through Malesia (Java – type) to New Guinea. Not found in Indochina.
ecology: Mostly in open places and at roadsides in secondary and primary forests: disturbed hill evergreen forests, open seasonally deciduous hardwood forests, moist places in seasonally deciduous hardwood forests with much bamboo; granite and shale bedrock, also on limestone; 550–1,680 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (only photo seen), Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP).
distribution: NE India (Assam, Sikkim (type)), Bangladesh, Bhutan, S China, Myanmar, Laos.
ecology: In evergreen forests, along streams, mixed pine forests; 600–1,000 m alt. Flowering: September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Luang NP, Doi Suthep, Chiang Dao WS, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Lon, Om Koi, Ban Mae Klang Luang, Hot), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phrae (Mae Krai), Tak (Umphang); Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Wong NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Pompee), Phetchaburi (Kaeng Kra Chan NP); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Pho Ta Luang Kaeo).

Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Doi Pui); Chiang Mai (Doi Ang Khang, San Chu, Doi Pha Hom Pok NP).
distribution: Nepal to S China (Yunnan), Bhutan, Myanmar (type).
ecology: Open grasslands, montane oak forests; 1,280–1,680 m alt. Flowering: August and October; fruiting: October, December and February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: Africa, N India (type), China (S Yunnan), E Java.
ecology: Sunny or shaded places in open forests; granite bedrock; 1,000–1,500 m alt. Flowering: November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam); Chiang Mai (Pha Mon, Doi Inthanon, Khun Wang; Mae Rim, Mae Chaem); NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani (Kumphawapi), Nong Khai, Maha Sarakham.
distribution: Widely distributed with several growth-forms (see notes): India and Sri Lanka to China and Japan (type), through Indochina, Java, eastern Malesia, southeast to New Caledonia, Australia, and into the Pacific, not in Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, or Borneo. Also in E Africa. Introduced in America.
ecology: Half-open places at forests edges, grass fields; annual forms in paddy fields; lowland up to 2,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: December–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: Africa, N India (type), China (S Yunnan), E Java.
ecology: Sunny or shaded places in open forests; granite bedrock; 1,000–1,500 m alt. Flowering: November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam); Chiang Mai (Pha Mon, Doi Inthanon, Khun Wang; Mae Rim, Mae Chaem); NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani (Kumphawapi), Nong Khai, Maha Sarakham.
distribution: Widely distributed with several growth-forms (see notes): India and Sri Lanka to China and Japan (type), through Indochina, Java, eastern Malesia, southeast to New Caledonia, Australia, and into the Pacific, not in Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, or Borneo. ecology: Half-open places at forests edges, grass fields; annual forms in paddy fields; lowland up to 2,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: December–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak (near Omkoi).
distribution: India, Sri Lanka, Nepal (type), Bhutan, Myanmar, S China.
ecology: Scattered in grassy moist places in open deciduous dipterocarp or mixed pine-dipterocarp forests, at 1,000–1,200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July and December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot), Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Lamung, 9 June 1922 – type: Kerr 6103, holotype -K, isotypes -BK E L TCD).
ecology: Dry open rocky grassy places; hills of ordovician limestone; 800–950 m alt. Flowering: June and December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Luang, Doi Pa Kao).
distribution: Afghanistan, India, Nepal (type), through Myanmar to S China.
ecology: Open grassy and rocky places; limestone ridges; 1,700–2,150 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Wiang Kaen Po Pha Tang), Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP).
distribution: N India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, through N Myanmar to N Laos and S China.
ecology: Exposed or among shrubs on rocky and grassy slopes, and in open hill evergreen forests; on limestone; 1,660–1,850 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Wiang Kaen Po Pha Tang), Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP).
distribution: N India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, through N Myanmar to N Laos and S China.
ecology: Exposed or among shrubs on rocky and grassy slopes, and in open hill evergreen forests; on limestone; 1,660–1,850 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–December.

ecology: Open grassy and rocky places; limestone ridges; 1,700–2,150 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–December.

ecology: Dry open rocky grassy places; hills of ordovician limestone; 800–950 m alt. Flowering: June and December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: India (Khasia – type), Bhutan, N Myanmar, China (Tibet, Sichuan, Yunnan).
ecology: Scattered in open grassy pine forests and near streams; 1,000–1,200 m alt. Flowering: December and January.

thailand: No specimens seen.
distribution: India, Sri Lanka, China (Guangdong), Vietnam, Malaysia, SW Asia (Iran), Africa, Europe, tropical America (naturalised).
ecology: Paddy fields, moist places along ditch sides.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: Widespread from tropical Africa through tropical Asia, S China, Malesia and Australia.
ecology: Paddy field margins, roadsides, grasslands along streams, 140–250 m alt.

ecology: In swamps and ponds; from sea level to 2,000 m alt.

ecology: Variable, especially in (eastern) Asia. Found in ponds, lakes, stagnant water, from low altitudes to over 2,000 m.

ecology: Variable, especially in (eastern) Asia. Found in ponds, lakes, stagnant water, from low altitudes to over 2,000 m.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Sop Moei); NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom (Phu Langka NP – Sirimongkol et al. 598).
distribution: Madagascar, Pakistan, India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, S China, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia (Java, Bali, Timor).
ecology: Shrub vegetation in areas with a (long) dry period; dry dipterocarp forests, on steep slopes, and near waterfalls; shale bedrock; 200–300 m alt. fruiting: February–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Tak, Nakhon Sawan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khlong Sip Ha).
distribution: Originally from S America (Mexico (type, not seen) and Guatemala), now widely cultivated and sometimes running wild.
ecology: Near houses in primary evergreen forests; 1,450 m alt.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
distribution: Widespread, introduced, etc from Central Asia, naturalised in western China (lectotype from European Mediterranean area, herb. Clifford 184, BM000628599).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Tha Song Yang-Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Chom Thong, Hot, Den Chaya, Doi Inthanon), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phrae (Mae Yom NP), Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Maha Sarakham; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Ko Si Chang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao, Pompi); CENTRAL: Nakhon Pathom (Mahidol University).
distribution: Widespread: Africa, S & SE Asia (China – type), Australia, introduced in America and Europe.
ecology: Lowland; soggy rice fields, wet open places; granite and shale bedrock, also on limestone. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year, but mainly from October–March.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Kanburi, only known from Smitinand 3850).
ecology: Scattered in wet localities at low altitudes. Fruiting: in November.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Kanburi, only known from Smitinand 3850).
ecology: Scattered in wet localities at low altitudes. Fruiting: in November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Tha Song Yang-Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Chom Thong, Hot, Den Chaya, Doi Inthanon), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phrae (Mae Yom NP), Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Maha Sarakham; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Ko Si Chang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao, Pompi); CENTRAL: Nakhon Pathom (Mahidol University).
distribution: Widespread: Africa, S & SE Asia (China – type), Australia, introduced in America and Europe.
ecology: Lowland; soggy rice fields, wet open places; granite and shale bedrock, also on limestone. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year, but mainly from October–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon NP); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Tat Ton); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Ban Kaeng), Chanthaburi (Pong Nam Ron).
distribution: Warmer parts of the world, widespread (Mexico – type).
ecology: Mixed deciduous forests along streams, wet places in rice fields and old clearings; 250–1,800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–November.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); CENTRAL: Saraburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ban Ta Sae), Songkhla (Tip Kiri Lake, Khuan Niang).
distribution: NE India, Myanmar (type), Laos, Vietnam S China (Kwangtung), Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia.
ecology: Open places, roadside ditches and adjacent flooded rice fields, in open ponds 30–50 cm deep, rooting in the muddy bottom; from sea level to 650 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: October–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Ang Khang, Doi Suthep, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Bo Luang, Omkoi, Mae Wang, Samoeng, Mae Taeng, Mai Mueang Nao Arboretum, Ban Nong Keo); Chiang Rai (Ban Lang Lat); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang).
distribution: India (type), Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, China (Yunnan), Japan, Taiwan.
ecology: Moist localities such as boggy places in dry dipterocarp forests, poor sandy soils, paddy fields, in mud-bottom drainage ditches, marshy edges of ponds, and moist savanna over clayey soil; granite bedrock; 550–1,300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: November–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Fang), Phrae (Mae Khaem); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan forest); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchnaburi (Huai Ban Kao); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Lamliang), Surat Thani (Ban Ta Mai), Songkhla (Chana).
distribution: SE Asia from Tajikistan, India (type), to N Korea and Japan, southwards to Java and Sri Lanka. Possibly indigenous in the area SW of the Caspian Sea. Introduced in various places in Europe, Africa, and N America.
ecology: Open muddy places, open nearly dry marshy areas in deciduous dipterocarp-oak forests, on disturbed fallow rice fields, near hot springs, in 10–20 cm deep water over mud; also on limestone; from sea level to 750 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July, and from November–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Ban Huai Nam Kao), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Mukdahan (Don Tan); PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Suan Tun Falls).
ecology: In moist ditches, along or in small ponds and puddles, in shallow water with muddy bottom, on wet sandy soil; granite bedrock; from sea level to 700 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Bo Luang, Doi Suthep – type of Rotala diversifolia : Hosseus 275, isotypes -K L; Mae Klang Falls, Omkoi); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao).
distribution: NE India (type), through SE Asia to New Guinea.
ecology: In moist places: near ponds, in clearings and deep forests, by streams and waterfalls; also on limestone; 350–1,200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: November–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Bo Luang, Doi Suthep – type of Rotala diversifolia : Hosseus 275, isotypes -K L; Mae Klang Falls, Omkoi); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao).
distribution: NE India (type), through SE Asia to New Guinea.
ecology: In moist places: near ponds, in clearings and deep forests, by streams and waterfalls; also on limestone; 350–1,200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: November–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Fang), Phrae (Mae Khaem); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan forest); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchnaburi (Huai Ban Kao); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Lamliang), Surat Thani (Ban Ta Mai), Songkhla (Chana).
distribution: SE Asia from Tajikistan, India (type), to N Korea and Japan, southwards to Java and Sri Lanka. Possibly indigenous in the area SW of the Caspian Sea. Introduced in various places in Europe, Africa, and N America.
ecology: Open muddy places, open nearly dry marshy areas in deciduous dipterocarp-oak forests, on disturbed fallow rice fields, near hot springs, in 10–20 cm deep water over mud; also on limestone; from sea level to 750 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July, and from November–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon NP); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Tat Ton); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Ban Kaeng), Chanthaburi (Pong Nam Ron).
distribution: Warmer parts of the world, widespread (Mexico – type).
ecology: Mixed deciduous forests along streams, wet places in rice fields and old clearings; 250–1,800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Ban Huai Nam Kao), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Mukdahan (Don Tan); PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Suan Tun Falls).
ecology: In moist ditches, along or in small ponds and puddles, in shallow water with muddy bottom, on wet sandy soil; granite bedrock; from sea level to 700 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Ang Khang, Doi Suthep, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Bo Luang, Omkoi, Mae Wang, Samoeng, Mae Taeng, Mai Mueang Nao Arboretum, Ban Nong Keo); Chiang Rai (Ban Lang Lat); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang).
distribution: India (type), Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, China (Yunnan), Japan, Taiwan.
ecology: Moist localities such as boggy places in dry dipterocarp forests, poor sandy soils, paddy fields, in mud-bottom drainage ditches, marshy edges of ponds, and moist savanna over clayey soil; granite bedrock; 550–1,300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: November–June.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); CENTRAL: Saraburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ban Ta Sae), Songkhla (Tip Kiri Lake, Khuan Niang).
distribution: NE India, Myanmar (type), Laos, Vietnam S China (Kwangtung), Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia.
ecology: Open places, roadside ditches and adjacent flooded rice fields, in open ponds 30–50 cm deep, rooting in the muddy bottom; from sea level to 650 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: October–February.

thailand: Cultivated. Occasionally planted in temple compounds and gardens.
ecology: Limestone or granite bedrock.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Thung Prong, Ko Si Chang, Ko Kaeo), Rayong (Ko Samet, Ban Phe), Trat (Ko Rang Yai); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Mueang District), Surat Thani (Ko Pha-ngan).
distribution: As the genus. Type not indicated.
ecology: Coastal shrub on or behind (coral) the beaches and on coastal limestone rocks, at low altitudes. Flowering and fruiting all year round.

thailand: A small ornamental tree or shrub, cultivated in temple compounds, gardens and parks in towns and villages, but seldom collected.
distribution: Himalayan regions, China, Indochina, Japan, Indonesia (Ambon – type, where apparently early introduced), widely cultivated all over the world.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Khao Buing (Huai Ban Kao – type: Geesink & Phengklai 6243, holotype -BKF, isotypes -K L).
ecology: Open places on limestone hills, including on the Ordovician limestone of Doi Hua Mot, with shrubs and stunted trees; 750–950 m alt. Flowering: April–June; fruiting: June, July, November, and December.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Khao Ang Rue Nai WS); PENINSULAR: Yala (Betong, Yaha, Than To); Narathiwat (To Mo – type of Lagerstroemia ovalifolia var. ruptilis : Lakshnakara 836, holotype -BM, isotype -K).
ecology: In open deciduous forests, dry evergreen forests and on riverbanks, at low altitudes. Flowering: May–August; fruiting: November–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chiang Mai University, Ban Bo Luang, Doi Suthep, Doi Kham, Doi Chiang Dao, Huai Kayo), Chiang Rai, Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP, Tat Moei Falls), Lampang (Chae Son NP, Chae Hom), Phrae (Mae Yom NP), Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Ban Huai Nam Pak), Mukdahan; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Sakae Rat, Nong Bun Mak), Si Sa Ket (Kantharalak, Khao Phra Wihan NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok), Ratchaburi (Kanburi); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Phu Khae Botanical Garden); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao – type of Lagerstroemia collettii : Kerr 1264, holotype -BM, isotypes -BK K).
ecology: Partly open places, mostly deciduous forests with oaks and dipterocarps, often along roads, often with much bamboo; granite and shale bedrock, also on limestone; 60–720 m alt. Flowering: June–August, also recorded in October; fruiting: October–December, also recorded in June and July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam, Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Doi Inthanon NP, Mae Taeng, Mae Rim, Fang, Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai (Doi Tam Tu Pu, Khun Kon Falls), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP, Li), Lampang (Chae Son NP, Doi Luang NP), Tak (Umphang), Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Prangkasi, Wangka – type of Lagerstroemia villosa var. sparsior : Kerr 10461, holotype -K, isotypes -BKF BM E).
ecology: Mostly open places, evergreen, evergreen seasonal and deciduous forests, often with much bamboo; granite, shale, and limestone bedrock; 150–1,125 m alt. Flowering: March–June; fruiting: April–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Ping ‘Me-ping’ – type of Lagerstroemia undulata : Hosseus 530, holotype -M, isotypes -BM E K L P).
ecology: Along rapids of the Mae Ping in primary forests and in scrub jungle, 200–350 m alt. Flowering: July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan (Tham Phet Tham Thong Forest Park); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP, Bua Yai), Buri Ram (Buri Ram, Khao Phanom Rung); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Ban Rai), Kanchanaburi (Kanchanaburi, Salak Phra WS, Wang Kanai), Ratchaburi (Chom Bueng, Tha Salao, Thung Kang Yang); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khao Samo Khon, Bandai Sam Saen Temple), Saraburi (Phra Phutthabat, Sam Lan, Ban Nong Bua, Wat Phu Khamwan, Me Sak – type of Lagerstroemia undulata var. subangulata : Kerr 7018, holotype -BK, isotypes -BM K).
ecology: Mixed deciduous forests and scrub, open rocky cliffs, dry deciduous thickets, often in open places; dense silt, sandstone, and limestone bedrock; from sea level to 200 m alt. Flowering: April–July; fruiting: October–December.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand

NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mae Hong Son, Mae Sarieng), Chiang Mai (Chiang Mai, Fang, Doi Inthanon, Doi Suthep – type of Lagerstroemia hossei : Hosseus 522, holotype -M; Mueang District, Ban Huai Gayo, Ban Me Dawk Deng, Mae Taeng), Chiang Rai (Mae Suai), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP, Don Chai Village – type of L. intermedia var. oblonga : Kerr 578, holotype -BM, isotypes -BKF K L), Phrae (Rong Kwang – type of L. macrocarpa var. reflexa : Bhusayallanit 18079, holotype -BKF), Tak (Doi Musoe, Umphang), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP), Kamphaeng Phet (Khlong Lan); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Wang Saphung Si Than); EASTERN: Buri Ram (Buri Ram to Sateuk), Si Sa Ket (Kanthararom – type of L. costa-draconis : Suvanakoses 1592, holotype -SING, isotypes -BKF KEP), Ubon Ratchathani (Ban Sanam Chai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Forest Research and Demonstration Centre, Sai Yok, Thung Yai Naresuan West WS, Neeckey); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan).
ecology: Deciduous dipterocarp oak forests with much bamboo, dry dipterocarp forests, pine-dipterocarp forests, and evergreen forests, along streams and roads, mostly in open places; on sandy soil, silt, granite, and limestone bedrock; 100–1,000 m alt. Flowering: March–June; fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Kamphaeng Phet; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Chong-Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khwae Noi Basin, Thung Yai Naresuan WS, Sangkhla Buri), Ratchaburi (Hin Dat), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Ban Pan Tawan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP [cultivated]), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Bang Son, Ta Ngo), Ranong (Kapoe), Pattani (Betong, Nikhom Kua Long), Narathiwat (Waeng).— Commonly planted as an ornamental tree throughout the country.
ecology: Trees of deciduous and evergreen forests, along rivers; sandy, and (rugged) limestone bedrock; from sea level to 750 m alt. Flowering: February–May; fruiting: April–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mu), Chiang Mai (Ban Mae Hia Nai, Huai Nam Dang NP, Doi Suthep – lectotype of Lagerstroemia tomentosa var. caudata : Hosseus 512, isolectotypes -BM, E; Doi Chiang Dao, Chai Prakan, Pong Duet Nature Park, Pong Duet Hot Springs, Mae Pah Boo), Chiang Rai (Doi Luang NP, Doi Thung), Phayao (Doi Luang NP, Doi Pha Chang WS), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Tak (Doi Musoe), Sukhothai, Nakhon Sawan (Mae Wong NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Three Pagodas, Prangkasi, Forest Research and Demonstration Centre, Sai Yok, Sangkhla Buri), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Khao Sam Roi Yot NP); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP).
ecology: Often open places; primary dry evergreen, seasonal, hardwood forests and mixed deciduous forests, often with much bamboo, also near streams and on riverbanks; granite, shale, phyllite, sandstone, and limestone bedrock; sea level to 1,150 m alt. Flowering: February–June; fruiting: probably all year round, but not collected in March, June, and October. The flowers are slightly fragrant.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Thale Ban NP, road between HQ and Malaysian border post, Gardner & Sidisunthorn 2922a & 2922b -BKF).
ecology: Rocky places, hillsides, and disturbed lowland evergreen-deciduous forests; limestone, but also recorded on quartzite and shale (see note); from sea level to 130 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: October; in Langkawi fruiting from November–February.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Chum Saeng, Sakae Rat Pak Thong Chai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan (Khao Sam Roi Yot NP, Hua Hin, Khao Chrongwan, Boekit Petjaboerie – type of Lagerstroemia loudonii : Teijsmann 5938, holotype -U); CENTRAL: Chai Nat, Lop Buri (Khao Samo Khon), Saraburi (Phu Khae, Hin Lap); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao, HQ Thung Pra, Khao Sip Ha Chan, Kaeng Hang Maeo, Wang Kaphae, Pong Nam Ron).
distribution: Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, cultivated elsewhere. Most collections are from doubtfully wild localities.
ecology: In evergreen forests, thickets, and shrub forests; granite and limestone bedrock; 20–350 m alt. Flowering: February–June; fruiting: February–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Phop Phra, Umphang)); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP), Nakhon Phanom (That Phanom), Khon Kaen (Mueang District, Mueang Phon); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang), Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Thong Chai), Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Wang Ka); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Khao Yai NP), Sa Kaeo (Khao Ang Rue Nai WS, Khao Takrup), Chachoengsao (Khao Ang Rue Nai WS), Chon Buri (Khao Khiao), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ban Na San), Satun (Tarutao NP).
ecology: In dry evergreen and mixed deciduous forests; granite bedrock, also on limestone; 50–900 m alt. Flowering: December–July; fruiting: April–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon NP, Doi Sang Liang, Mae Chaem, Doi Suthep, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Ban Bo Luang, Wachirathan Falls, Pa Da Cave, Hot, Mae Soi Valley, Mae Tuen Watershed Station, Hot), Nan, Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Doi Luang NP), Phrae (Mae Yom NP), Tak (Lan Sang, Umphang), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang), Kamphaeng Phet (Khlong Lan); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Wang Saphung – type of Lagerstroemia noei var. longifolia : Dee 707, holotype -BKF), Udon Thani (Nong Han), Mukdahan (Fai Huai Din Dam); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Chum Phae), Ubon Ratchathani (Chiet); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Kanburi – type of L. cochinchinensis var. ovalifolia : Phusomsaeng (‘P.S.’) 2101, holotype -SING), Ratchaburi (Ta Salao); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khao Wongkot Temple, Lam Narai, Khao Samo Khon), Saraburi (Khao Song Phi Nong, Ban Khrua, Sam Lan, Khao Talu); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao, Ko Si Chang), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao), Chon Buri (Si Racha – lectotype of L. collinsae : Collins 190 [K729710], holotype -K, isotypes -BM BK E).
distribution: Myanmar, China (Hainan), Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam (Pierre 820, lectotype of
ecology: In mixed evergreen and deciduous forests, often with bamboo, in thickets, scattered in open, dry or wet, deciduous dipterocarp forests, also along roads; granite, shale, and (rugged) limestone bedrock; 50–1,000 m alt. Flowering: January–August; fruiting: February–December.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Bueng Kan (Chet Si Falls, Bung Khla); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Chum Saeng – type of Lagerstroemia noei : Noe 246, holotype -BM, isotypes -BK K), Buri Ram (Khao Phanom Rung), Si Sa Ket (S of Kantharalak, Phanom Dongrak WS), Ubon Ratchathani (Ban Thung Luang, Na Chaluai, Khong Chiam); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Khao Ang Ruenai WS).
ecology: Scattered in open dry deciduous dipterocarp forests on sandstone; 200–325 m alt. Flowering: May–September and also in November; fruiting: May and from August–November.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom (Si Songkhram; Tha Uthen, That Phanom – type of Lagerstroemia spireana var. armata : Kerr 8423, holotype -K, isotypes -BKF BM E), Bueng Kan (Bung Khla, Bueng Khong Long, Seka), Sakon Nakhon (Wanon Niwat, Sawang Daen Din).
ecology: Swampy areas, evergreen scrubby creeks; ca 200 m alt. Flowering: May, June, and October; fruiting: May, June, October and February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Phop Phra, Umphang)); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP), Nakhon Phanom (That Phanom), Khon Kaen (Mueang District, Mueang Phon); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang), Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Thong Chai), Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Wang Ka); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Khao Yai NP), Sa Kaeo (Khao Ang Rue Nai WS, Khao Takrup), Chachoengsao (Khao Ang Rue Nai WS), Chon Buri (Khao Khiao), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ban Na San), Satun (Tarutao NP).
ecology: In dry evergreen and mixed deciduous forests; granite bedrock, also on limestone; 50–900 m alt. Flowering: December–July; fruiting: April–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon NP, Doi Sang Liang, Mae Chaem, Doi Suthep, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Ban Bo Luang, Wachirathan Falls, Pa Da Cave, Hot, Mae Soi Valley, Mae Tuen Watershed Station, Hot), Nan, Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Doi Luang NP), Phrae (Mae Yom NP), Tak (Lan Sang, Umphang), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang), Kamphaeng Phet (Khlong Lan); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Wang Saphung – type of Lagerstroemia noei var. longifolia : Dee 707, holotype -BKF), Udon Thani (Nong Han), Mukdahan (Fai Huai Din Dam); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Chum Phae), Ubon Ratchathani (Chiet); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Kanburi – type of L. cochinchinensis var. ovalifolia : Phusomsaeng (‘P.S.’) 2101, holotype -SING), Ratchaburi (Ta Salao); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khao Wongkot Temple, Lam Narai, Khao Samo Khon), Saraburi (Khao Song Phi Nong, Ban Khrua, Sam Lan, Khao Talu); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao, Ko Si Chang), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao), Chon Buri (Si Racha – lectotype of L. collinsae : Collins 190 [K729710], holotype -K, isotypes -BM BK E).
distribution: Myanmar, China (Hainan), Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam (Pierre 820, lectotype of
ecology: In mixed evergreen and deciduous forests, often with bamboo, in thickets, scattered in open, dry or wet, deciduous dipterocarp forests, also along roads; granite, shale, and (rugged) limestone bedrock; 50–1,000 m alt. Flowering: January–August; fruiting: February–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Ping ‘Me-ping’ – type of Lagerstroemia undulata : Hosseus 530, holotype -M, isotypes -BM E K L P).
ecology: Along rapids of the Mae Ping in primary forests and in scrub jungle, 200–350 m alt. Flowering: July.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Khao Buing (Huai Ban Kao – type: Geesink & Phengklai 6243, holotype -BKF, isotypes -K L).
ecology: Open places on limestone hills, including on the Ordovician limestone of Doi Hua Mot, with shrubs and stunted trees; 750–950 m alt. Flowering: April–June; fruiting: June, July, November, and December.

thailand: A small ornamental tree or shrub, cultivated in temple compounds, gardens and parks in towns and villages, but seldom collected.
distribution: Himalayan regions, China, Indochina, Japan, Indonesia (Ambon – type, where apparently early introduced), widely cultivated all over the world.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Thale Ban NP, road between HQ and Malaysian border post, Gardner & Sidisunthorn 2922a & 2922b -BKF).
ecology: Rocky places, hillsides, and disturbed lowland evergreen-deciduous forests; limestone, but also recorded on quartzite and shale (see note); from sea level to 130 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: October; in Langkawi fruiting from November–February.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Chum Saeng, Sakae Rat Pak Thong Chai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan (Khao Sam Roi Yot NP, Hua Hin, Khao Chrongwan, Boekit Petjaboerie – type of Lagerstroemia loudonii : Teijsmann 5938, holotype -U); CENTRAL: Chai Nat, Lop Buri (Khao Samo Khon), Saraburi (Phu Khae, Hin Lap); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao, HQ Thung Pra, Khao Sip Ha Chan, Kaeng Hang Maeo, Wang Kaphae, Pong Nam Ron).
distribution: Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, cultivated elsewhere. Most collections are from doubtfully wild localities.
ecology: In evergreen forests, thickets, and shrub forests; granite and limestone bedrock; 20–350 m alt. Flowering: February–June; fruiting: February–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mae Hong Son, Mae Sarieng), Chiang Mai (Chiang Mai, Fang, Doi Inthanon, Doi Suthep – type of Lagerstroemia hossei : Hosseus 522, holotype -M; Mueang District, Ban Huai Gayo, Ban Me Dawk Deng, Mae Taeng), Chiang Rai (Mae Suai), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP, Don Chai Village – type of L. intermedia var. oblonga : Kerr 578, holotype -BM, isotypes -BKF K L), Phrae (Rong Kwang – type of L. macrocarpa var. reflexa : Bhusayallanit 18079, holotype -BKF), Tak (Doi Musoe, Umphang), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP), Kamphaeng Phet (Khlong Lan); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Wang Saphung Si Than); EASTERN: Buri Ram (Buri Ram to Sateuk), Si Sa Ket (Kanthararom – type of L. costa-draconis : Suvanakoses 1592, holotype -SING, isotypes -BKF KEP), Ubon Ratchathani (Ban Sanam Chai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Forest Research and Demonstration Centre, Sai Yok, Thung Yai Naresuan West WS, Neeckey); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan).
ecology: Deciduous dipterocarp oak forests with much bamboo, dry dipterocarp forests, pine-dipterocarp forests, and evergreen forests, along streams and roads, mostly in open places; on sandy soil, silt, granite, and limestone bedrock; 100–1,000 m alt. Flowering: March–June; fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Bueng Kan (Chet Si Falls, Bung Khla); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Chum Saeng – type of Lagerstroemia noei : Noe 246, holotype -BM, isotypes -BK K), Buri Ram (Khao Phanom Rung), Si Sa Ket (S of Kantharalak, Phanom Dongrak WS), Ubon Ratchathani (Ban Thung Luang, Na Chaluai, Khong Chiam); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Khao Ang Ruenai WS).
ecology: Scattered in open dry deciduous dipterocarp forests on sandstone; 200–325 m alt. Flowering: May–September and also in November; fruiting: May and from August–November.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Khao Ang Rue Nai WS); PENINSULAR: Yala (Betong, Yaha, Than To); Narathiwat (To Mo – type of Lagerstroemia ovalifolia var. ruptilis : Lakshnakara 836, holotype -BM, isotype -K).
ecology: In open deciduous forests, dry evergreen forests and on riverbanks, at low altitudes. Flowering: May–August; fruiting: November–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Kamphaeng Phet; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Chong-Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khwae Noi Basin, Thung Yai Naresuan WS, Sangkhla Buri), Ratchaburi (Hin Dat), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Ban Pan Tawan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP [cultivated]), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Bang Son, Ta Ngo), Ranong (Kapoe), Pattani (Betong, Nikhom Kua Long), Narathiwat (Waeng).— Commonly planted as an ornamental tree throughout the country.
ecology: Trees of deciduous and evergreen forests, along rivers; sandy, and (rugged) limestone bedrock; from sea level to 750 m alt. Flowering: February–May; fruiting: April–January.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom (Si Songkhram; Tha Uthen, That Phanom – type of Lagerstroemia spireana var. armata : Kerr 8423, holotype -K, isotypes -BKF BM E), Bueng Kan (Bung Khla, Bueng Khong Long, Seka), Sakon Nakhon (Wanon Niwat, Sawang Daen Din).
ecology: Swampy areas, evergreen scrubby creeks; ca 200 m alt. Flowering: May, June, and October; fruiting: May, June, October and February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan (Tham Phet Tham Thong Forest Park); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP, Bua Yai), Buri Ram (Buri Ram, Khao Phanom Rung); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Ban Rai), Kanchanaburi (Kanchanaburi, Salak Phra WS, Wang Kanai), Ratchaburi (Chom Bueng, Tha Salao, Thung Kang Yang); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khao Samo Khon, Bandai Sam Saen Temple), Saraburi (Phra Phutthabat, Sam Lan, Ban Nong Bua, Wat Phu Khamwan, Me Sak – type of Lagerstroemia undulata var. subangulata : Kerr 7018, holotype -BK, isotypes -BM K).
ecology: Mixed deciduous forests and scrub, open rocky cliffs, dry deciduous thickets, often in open places; dense silt, sandstone, and limestone bedrock; from sea level to 200 m alt. Flowering: April–July; fruiting: October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mu), Chiang Mai (Ban Mae Hia Nai, Huai Nam Dang NP, Doi Suthep – lectotype of Lagerstroemia tomentosa var. caudata : Hosseus 512, isolectotypes -BM, E; Doi Chiang Dao, Chai Prakan, Pong Duet Nature Park, Pong Duet Hot Springs, Mae Pah Boo), Chiang Rai (Doi Luang NP, Doi Thung), Phayao (Doi Luang NP, Doi Pha Chang WS), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Tak (Doi Musoe), Sukhothai, Nakhon Sawan (Mae Wong NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Three Pagodas, Prangkasi, Forest Research and Demonstration Centre, Sai Yok, Sangkhla Buri), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Khao Sam Roi Yot NP); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP).
ecology: Often open places; primary dry evergreen, seasonal, hardwood forests and mixed deciduous forests, often with much bamboo, also near streams and on riverbanks; granite, shale, phyllite, sandstone, and limestone bedrock; sea level to 1,150 m alt. Flowering: February–June; fruiting: probably all year round, but not collected in March, June, and October. The flowers are slightly fragrant.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chiang Mai University, Ban Bo Luang, Doi Suthep, Doi Kham, Doi Chiang Dao, Huai Kayo), Chiang Rai, Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP, Tat Moei Falls), Lampang (Chae Son NP, Chae Hom), Phrae (Mae Yom NP), Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Ban Huai Nam Pak), Mukdahan; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Sakae Rat, Nong Bun Mak), Si Sa Ket (Kantharalak, Khao Phra Wihan NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok), Ratchaburi (Kanburi); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Phu Khae Botanical Garden); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao – type of Lagerstroemia collettii : Kerr 1264, holotype -BM, isotypes -BK K).
ecology: Partly open places, mostly deciduous forests with oaks and dipterocarps, often along roads, often with much bamboo; granite and shale bedrock, also on limestone; 60–720 m alt. Flowering: June–August, also recorded in October; fruiting: October–December, also recorded in June and July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam, Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Doi Inthanon NP, Mae Taeng, Mae Rim, Fang, Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai (Doi Tam Tu Pu, Khun Kon Falls), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP, Li), Lampang (Chae Son NP, Doi Luang NP), Tak (Umphang), Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Prangkasi, Wangka – type of Lagerstroemia villosa var. sparsior : Kerr 10461, holotype -K, isotypes -BKF BM E).
ecology: Mostly open places, evergreen, evergreen seasonal and deciduous forests, often with much bamboo; granite, shale, and limestone bedrock; 150–1,125 m alt. Flowering: March–June; fruiting: April–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Kalasin; EASTERN: Si Sa Ket; CENTRAL: Chai Nat, Suphan Buri, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Samut Prakan; SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phatthalung, Songkhla.
distribution: Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Laos, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Vietnam, widespread in Africa, S & SE Asia, Australia.
ecology: Wet swampy places, flooded rice paddies, often floating in water at edges of ponds, tanks, ditches, near sea level to 1,550 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala.
distribution: S America, from Chile and Argentina to Venezuela and Colombia, through C America to S Mexico, Greater Antilles, and S United States. Introduced widely from India, Sri Lanka, to Indonesia.
ecology: From sea level to 2,600 m alt. in wet habitats such as swamps inundated during the rainy season, ditches and drainage canals, sloughs, swales, marshy shores, and wet clearings.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai, Nan, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Mukdahan; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Satun (Thale Ban), Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Laos, Malaya, Myanmar, Singapore, Vietnam; widespread in Africa, S & SW Asia, Australasia, Europe, N America, Pacific Islands, S America.
ecology: Moist to wet places along streams, ponds or lakes, often on disturbed and/or cultivated sites, common and widespread; near sea level to 2,200 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Tak, Sukhothai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Nakhon Phanom, Mukdahan, Kalasin, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Buri Ram, Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Chai Nat; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Chai Nat, Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga, Trang, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Nepal, the Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Vietnam; widespread in Africa, SE Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands, S America.
ecology: Scattered to common in open wet often disturbed areas, stream sides, roadside ditches, clear agricultural land, or openings in moist forests, near sea level to 500 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (San Sai, Fang, Hot Springs), Sukhothai, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Si Sa Ket; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Songkhla.
distribution: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Laos, Myanmar, Vietnam, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Africa including Madagascar, SW & SE Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands (New Caledonia).
ecology: Wet sites such as flood plains, roadside ditches, muddy wallows, or abandoned rice paddies; near sea level to 1,200 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Klang, Chom Thong, Sa Maing); NORTH-EASTERN: Mukdahan (Phu Pha Yon NP); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Pattani, Yala.
distribution: China, India, Indonesia, Nepal, the Philippines, Sri Lanka.
ecology: Wet sites such as rice paddies, flood plains, stream sides, near sea level to 800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Klang, Chom Thong, Sa Maing); NORTH-EASTERN: Mukdahan (Phu Pha Yon NP); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Pattani, Yala.
distribution: China, India, Indonesia, Nepal, the Philippines, Sri Lanka.
ecology: Wet sites such as rice paddies, flood plains, stream sides, near sea level to 800 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lampang, Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri.
distribution: Pakistan, India (type), Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Laos, S China (Yunnan).
ecology: In evergreen forests, mixed deciduous forests and bamboo forests over granite and shale, also found in thorn scrub; 100–1,050 m alt. Flowering: mainly September–December.

thailand: EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Ubon Ratchathani.
ecology: In grass in evergreen oak forests; 250–900 m alt. Flowering: June–July August).

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan, Tak (Ban Na Gorge – type: Kerr 288, holotype -K).
ecology: In mixed or hill evergreen forests; ca 1,070 m alt. Flowering: September–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei.
ecology: In deciduous forests, also in limestone crevices; 900–2,000 m alt. Flowering: August–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Lamphun, Tak (Wangchao – type: Hosseus 77, lectotype -K), Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Buri Ram; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi.
ecology: In primary or secondary deciduous forests over limestone, granite and shale; 50–900 m alt. Flowering: mainly July–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – Tripetch s.n. -QBG).
ecology: In humus in limestone area; ca 1,600 m alt. Flowering: August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai ( Doi Suthep – type: Kerr 194, holotype -K, isotypes -C L P); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Ubon Ratchathani.
ecology: In humous or sandy soil in deciduous forests, hill evergreen forests and pine forests over granite or shale; 190–1,200 m alt. Flowering: mainly June–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai, Sukhothai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat.
ecology: In sandy soil in dipterocarp forests, pine forests and savanna; sea level to about 1,300 m alt. Flowering: mainly July–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Nan, Phitsanulok.
ecology: In open pine forests, seasonal evergreen forests and grasslands, mostly over granite; 1,100–2,000 m alt. Flowering: July–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lamphun, Lampang, Phrae, Tak, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Lop Buri, Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: unlocalised.
ecology: In humid or dry soil in seasonal evergreen forests, deciduous forests, pine forests and bamboo forests over sandstone, granite, shale and limestone, also recorded in disturbed sites; 10–900 m alt. Flowering: mainly August–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Doi Pha Khao – type: Garrett 687, holotype -K, isotype -BKF), Chiang Mai.
ecology: In evergreen forests; 960–1,550 m alt. Flowering: July–August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai (fide Seidenf., Dansk Bot. Ark. 31 (3): 102. 1977), Phayao, Lamphun, Lampang, Phrae, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Udon Thani, Sakon Nakhon, Kalasin (fide Seidenfaden, op. cit.); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH EASTERN: Prachin Buri.
distribution: Myanmar (type), Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, S China.
ecology: In deciduous and bamboo forests over shale or limestone and rarely in evergreen forests, also recorded in disturbed sites: 50–1,300 m alt. Flowering: mainly August–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lamphun, Lampang, Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima.
distribution: NE India, Myanmar, S China, Laos, Vietnam, the Philippines (type).
ecology: In deciduous, seasonal evergreen and pine forests over granite, limestone and phyllite, often found together with Habenaria dentata (Sw.) Schltr., also reported in disturbed sites; 300–1,300 m alt. Flowering: mainly July–November

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Kalasin; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri.
ecology: In deciduous forests and open pine-oak forests, sometimes in grassy forests clearings; 280–1,025 m alt. Flowering: August–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Lampang, Phrae.
distribution: Pakistan, India (type), Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar, S China (Yunnan).
ecology: In deciduous forests over sandstone, also recorded in rice field bunds; 190–1,100 m alt. Flowering: September–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Kamphaeng Phet, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH EASTERN: Loei, Nong Khai (fide Seidenf., Dansk Bot. Ark. 31(3): 84.1977); CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Pungah – type: Hamiff & Nur 3858, holotype -SING, isotype -K).
distribution: S China (Yunnan), Cambodia, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia (Kedah).
ecology: In mixed deciduous or in evergreen forests over granite, also reported in bamboo thicket; 100–375 m alt. Flowering: August–November(–December).

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: (fide Vaddhanaphuti, Field Guide Wild Orchids Thail. ed. 4: 166. 2005).
ecology: Mostly unknown, one collection reported in a limestone crevice at 600 m alt. Flowering: June–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: NE India (type), Nepal, Vietnam, S China, S Japan.
ecology: In forests and grasslands; 1,500–2,000 m alt. Flowering: July–August.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (fide P. Tripetch), Rayong (Khao Chamao NP – Tripetch 005 -QBG).
ecology: In open area in soil among granite rocks, ca 100 m alt. Flowering: May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Lamphun, Tak (Wangchao – type: Hosseus 53, lectotype -P); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (fide P. Tripetch).
ecology: In deciduous forests over shale; 130–700 m alt. Flowering: September.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Songkhla.
distribution: ?India, Laos, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: In evergreen forests with dipterocarps and rattan, often among or on limestone rocks; 125–1,200 m alt. Flowering: July–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga.
distribution: India, Nepal (type), S China, Cambodia, Vietnam, Sumatra.
ecology: In humid places in bamboo thicket and scrubland over sandstone and limestone, also in limestone crevices; 150–825 m alt. Flowering: August, November.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand

Ark. 31(3): 110. 1977], Trang, Songkhla, Pattani.
distribution: S China, Laos, Cambodia (type), Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia.
ecology: In open areas in deciduous forests, scrub vegetation or in savanna over granite, also in marshy places; from near sea level to 1,120 m alt. Flowering: mainly June–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon, Mukdahan; EASTERN: Amnat Charoen, Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
distribution: Myanmar (type), Laos, Vietnam, S China (Sichuan, Yunnan).
ecology: In open areas in deciduous or seasonal evergreen forests, in pine forests and savanna; 50–1,120 m alt. Flowering: mainly July–September.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak (Wang Chao – type: Hosseus 52, lectotype -K, isolectotypes -AMES BM L); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon.
ecology: In grassy places in open forests; 170–1,500 m alt. Flowering: August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani.
distribution: India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, S China, Vietnam, the Philippines, S Japan.
ecology: In primary evergreen forests, reported over granite and limestone; 500–1,700 m alt. Flowering: July–September October).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (foothills of Doi Chiang Dao – type: Geesink et al. 5759, holotype -L, isotype -BKF), Phayao, Lampang, Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong.
ecology: In dry deciduous forests over granite, shale or limestone, often growing in bamboo-rich areas, also reported in evergreen forests; 20–645 m alt. Flowering: mainly May–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Sukhothai (Srichaliang – type: Kasem 259 -BK C).
ecology: Unknown.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Tak; SOUTH WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
ecology: In limestone crevices in full sun or partial shade in evergreen or deciduous forests and on mountain summits; 740–1,800 m alt. Flowering: June–September.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi.
distribution: India (type), Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, S China (Guanxi), Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam.
ecology: In damp grassy areas, on one collector’s label recorded as common in rice fields, not recorded, Flowering: July–September.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nong Khai (Phu Wua).
distribution: NE India (type), Myanmar, SE Tibet, S China, Vietnam.
ecology: In rock crevices or in shallow layers of sand and humus on exposed sandstone with seeping water in upper mixed deciduous forests; ca 400 m alt. Flowering: September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phayao (Phu Langka), Nan (Doi Phu Kha), Tak (Doi Hua Mot).
distribution: N India, Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar, S China, Manchuria, Korea, Japan, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia, Java (type), Sulawesi, Timor, the Philippines.
ecology: Grass-dominated vegetation on roadside verges, clearings, exposed ridges and other open places in hill evergreen forests on limestone or granite bedrock: 900–2,300 m alt. Flowering: July–October(–December).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
ecology: Crevices of limestone cliffs in hill evergreen forests, seasonal evergreen forests and bamboo thickets; 640–1,700 m alt. Flowering: July–August(–October).

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot – type: Suksathan 3000, holotype -QBG).
ecology: Rock crevices and exposed grassy slopes on limestone: ca 1,000 m alt. Flowering: June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot).
ecology: Scrub and open grassy slopes on limestone; ca 1,000 m alt. Flowering: May–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type: Watthana & Suksathan 1274, holotype -QBG).

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot – type: Suksathan 3000, holotype -QBG).
ecology: Rock crevices and exposed grassy slopes on limestone: ca 1,000 m alt. Flowering: June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type: Watthana & Suksathan 1274, holotype -QBG).

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP – syntypes: Cumberlege 1190, C K).
ecology: Terrestrial in grasslands, 700–800 m alt. Apparently very rare, this species’ inconspicuous habit among over-topping grasses probably makes it overlooked and under recorded. Its occurrence at other localities within the disjunct range given here seems likely. Flowering: May–June, leaf present from late June–December.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP – type: Jirawatkavi 4, holotype -BKF).
ecology: Terrestrial growing in leaf litter in lowland rainforests, 700–800 m alt. Flowering: March, leaf present from late March–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Sukhothai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Surin, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Prachin Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Satun; UNSPECIFIED: Khao Yai NP [comprising parts of the provinces of Nakhon Ratchasima, Saraburi, Prachin Buri and Nakhon Nayok].

ecology: Terrestrial in open grassy ground in often degraded dipterocarp, oak, pine, bamboo or evergreen broad-leaved forests or scrub, also in savanna and in swampy areas, sea level to 1,300 m alt. Recorded over sandstone and quartzite. Flowering: (December–)February– March(–May).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Sukhothai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Surin, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Prachin Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Satun; UNSPECIFIED: Khao Yai NP [comprising parts of the provinces of Nakhon Ratchasima, Saraburi, Prachin Buri and Nakhon Nayok].
distribution: India, ?Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, S & SW China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Andaman Islands, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java (type), Lesser Sunda Islands, Borneo, Sulawesi, Maluku, New Guinea, NE Australia (Northern Territory, Queensland), New Caledonia.
ecology: Terrestrial in open grassy ground in often degraded dipterocarp, oak, pine, bamboo or evergreen broad-leaved forests or scrub, also in savanna and in swampy areas, sea level to 1,300 m alt. Recorded over sandstone and quartzite. Flowering: (December–)February– March(–May).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak.
distribution: Pakistan, N & NE India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar, SW China, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Taiwan, Korea, Japan, Ryukyus; 1,100–1,600 m alt.
ecology: In open forests in humus-filled rock fissures. Flowering: May and June.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan.
distribution: N India (Meghalaya: Khasia Hills), Myanmar, Vietnam, C & S China (type), Taiwan, Ryukyus; 1,000–1,600 m alt.
ecology: In semi-shaded spots in lower montane evergreen forests in moist well drained places. Flowering: October–March.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang).
distribution: Nepal, NE India (Sikkim, Meghalaya), Bhutan, S China (Yunnan) and possibly Laos and Vietnam; 1,200–1,450 m alt. Iconotype in Paxton, Paxton’s Mag. Bot. 10: 97–98. 1843.
ecology: Epiphyte on mossy rocks and mossy trees where humus and leaf litter have accumulated in evergreen montane forests, in dappled shade. Flowering: March and April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
distribution: N India [Sikkim, Assam (type)], Bhutan, Myanmar, S China, Taiwan, Ryukyus, Japan, the Philippines (Luzon), Cambodia, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Borneo (Sabah); 1,200–1,600 m alt
ecology: Epiphyte in hollows on the limbs and trunks of trees or on rotten logs or humus-covered rocks in evergreen montane forests, often in full sun. Flowering: August–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lampang, Phrae; NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon, Mukdahan; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok, Nonthaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao, Chon Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Satun.
distribution: Nepal, India, Andaman Islands, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, S China, Hong Kong, Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java. Iconotype in Rheede, Hort. Malab. 12(8): t. 8. 1703.
ecology: In the forks and hollows of large branches and tree trunks, usually in open forests in partial shade provided by the leaf canopy, also on limestone rocks; sea level–1,500 m alt. Flowering: (March–)April–June(–August).

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani; CENTRAL: Nonthaburi, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla.
distribution: S Indochina (type from Vietnam), Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Borneo, widely in the Philippines, Sulawesi and W Java; from sea level to 300 m alt.
ecology: On trees in open lowland forests or secondary forests or on exposed coastal rocks, often in full sun. Flowering: April–September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Bukit Bunga), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Hainan, S Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo, the Philippines; from sea level to 1,200 m alt.
ecology: In the forks of forests trees, and occasionally on rocks, usually in lowland evergreen and riverine forests and often near the sea. Flowering: usually March–May, although it can flower at other times of the year.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi.
ecology: Epiphytic on tree trunks, decaying tree fragments and fallen trees (usually less than 1 m above the ground) in lowland freshwater swamp forests. Flowering: February–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Soi Dao – Suddee et al. 2160 -BKF).
distribution: NE India (Nagaland), Myanmar (type), China (W Yunnan); 1,500–2,700 m alt.
ecology: On moist rocks, rock crevices, and trees in damp shaded evergreen forests, often near or overhanging streams. Flowering: March–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang – type: Menzies & Du Puy 501, holotype -K).
ecology: In shallow sandy soil in low open Pinus-Ericaceae woodland in the shade of low bushes in areas with many rocky outcrops and boulders of sandstone; 1,400–1,600 m alt. Flowering: December–May.,

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei.
distribution: N India (Sikkim, Meghalaya, Manipur), Myanmar, S China (NW to SE Yunnan); 1,350–1,600 m alt. Type prepared from a cultivated plant of unknown provenance.
ecology: On rocks and trees in evergreen forests, often in deep shade, in humus, moss or on rotting wood. Flowering: September–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: province undisclosed (type: sine coll., cult. Wada s.n., holotype -TNS).
ecology: No data available on habitat or altitudinal range. Flowering: recorded in March and April in cultivation.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai.
distribution: NE and E Myanmar (type), S & W Yunnan; 1,200–2,000 m alt.
ecology: On trees in damp shaded evergreen or mixed forests, often on Schima wallichii, or on shaded cliffs along valleys. Flowering: February–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Soi Dao – Suphuntee et al. 805 -BKF QBG).
ecology: Hill evergreen forests. Flowering: August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
distribution: E Nepal, N India (Sikkim Assam), Myanmar, China (N Yunnan, SW Sichuan and SE Xizang); 1,500–2,600 m alt. Type prepared from a cultivated plant of unknown provenance.
ecology: Grows as an epiphyte on trees in damp, shady forests or on steep banks or rocks, often where thick moss cover occurs. Flowering: January–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan.
distribution: China (S and W Yunnan), E & N Myanmar; 1,200–1,900 m alt. Type prepared from a cultivated plant of unknown provenance.
ecology: On moist rocks, fallen trees, and trees in damp shaded evergreen forests, often near or overhanging streams, also on isolated trees in secondary grasslands. Flowering: November–March.

ecology: In the forks and hollows of large branches and tree trunks, usually in open forests in partial shade provided by the leaf canopy, also on limestone rocks; sea level–1,500 m alt. Flowering: (March–)April–June(–August).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Bukit Bunga), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Hainan, S Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo, the Philippines; from sea level to 1,200 m alt.
ecology: In the forks of forests trees, and occasionally on rocks, usually in lowland evergreen and riverine forests and often near the sea. Flowering: usually March–May, although it can flower at other times of the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Soi Dao – Suphuntee et al. 805 -BKF QBG).
ecology: Hill evergreen forests. Flowering: August.

thailand: NORTHERN: province undisclosed (type: sine coll., cult. Wada s.n., holotype -TNS).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai (Mae Chedi), Phayao, Nan, Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang, Tak, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan (Takhli); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao), Loei, Mukdahan (Phu Mano); EASTERN: Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Krabi, Trang (Thung Khai), Satun (Ban Rao Pla), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Sri Lanka, India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Indochina, S China (Yunnan, Jiangxi) and throughout Malesia to the W Pacific Islands (southeast to Tonga).
ecology: seasonal evergreen forests, mixed deciduous forests, dry deciduous dipterocarp forests, hill evergreen forests, savanna forests, pine forests, bamboo thickets, rubber plantations, roadsides and old forests clearings, 100–2,100 m alt. Flowering all year round, but mainly March–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan), Nakhon Phanom (Tha Uthen), Khon Kaen (Phu Wiang); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Si Sa Ket (Ban Chia); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nong Bua Deng), Chon Buri (Si Racha).
distribution: Myanmar (type), Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia and possibly Sikkim.
ecology: Seasonal evergreen forests, mixed deciduous forests, dry deciduous dipterocarp forests and pine forests; 0–1,100 m alt. Flowering: February–April.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha); PENINSULAR: Yala.
distribution: Sri Lanka, India, Myanmar, Vietnam, S & SE China, Taiwan, Japan and across Malesia (widespread, type from Java) to Queensland.
ecology: Tropical rain forests, seasonal evergreen forests and once recorded from a rubber plantation with bamboo, 200–950 m alt. Flowering: April–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan (Pak Nam Pho); SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong (Chak Phong).
distribution: Southern Himalayas (type from Nepal), NE India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Hainan, Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, the Philippines, New Guinea, Bismarck Archipelago, N & W Australia.
ecology: Freshwater swamps; 0–50 m alt. Flowering: recorded in April and December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan (Pak Nam Pho); EASTERN: Si Sa Ket (Khao Phra Wihan), Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Pathum Thani.
ecology: Open, marshy places (recorded from a “swamp” in Nakhon Sawan and from “

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani (Mueang District – type: Kerr 0135, holotype -K); EASTERN: Si Sa Ket (Lalai).
ecology: Lower mixed deciduous forests and savanna forests; 200–650 m alt. Flowering: March–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Lumphun (Mae Ping); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun.
distribution: India, Nepal (type), Myanmar, S China, Laos, Vietnam.
ecology: Dry deciduous dipterocarp forests; ca 550 m alt. Flowering: recorded in March and May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thong Pha Phum).
ecology: Teak forests and mixed deciduous forests; 550–650 m alt. Flowering: September–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Kerr 107, holotype -K, isotype -TCD), Phayao; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Phu Luang), Si Sa Ket (Kantharalak).
ecology: Seasonal evergreen forests, dry deciduous dipterocarp forests and savanna forests, 350–850 m alt. Flowering: August–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Phayao; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Wang Nam Khiao), Surin (Kap Choeng).
ecology: Dipterocarp forests, usually on sandy soil; 350–850 m alt. Flowering: recorded in May–June and August–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phrae (Ban Mae Phuak), Tak, Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao), Sakon Nakhon (Ban Kut Na Kham), Mukdahan; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Phak Pang), Si Sa Ket (Ban Chia), Ubon Ratchathani (Khong Chiam); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Ban Tha Chang), Chon Buri, Rayong (Ko Samet), Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Tako), Ranong (Kapoe), Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi (Ko Chum), Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang (Ko Libong), Songkhla, Yala (Betong), Narathiwat (Tak Bai).
distribution: Sri Lanka, Pakistan, India, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, S China, Indochina, Ryukyus, Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore (type), Sumatra, Java, Borneo, the Philippines, Guam; additionally some presumably anthropochorous occurrences in East Timor, Australia, S Africa and Florida.
ecology: Coastal heath forests, lower tropical rain forests, seasonal evergreen forests, deciduous forests, scrub, crevices of limestone cliffs, open sandy soil along freshwater swamps and river banks, ruderal ground, clearings, roadsides and as a weed on arable ground; 0–750 m alt. Flowering all year round, but mainly December–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Thong Chai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Khao Yoi).
distribution: India (type), Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar, S China (Yunnan, Guangxi), Laos.
ecology: Seasonal evergreen forests, savanna forests and open grassy ground; 150–900 m alt. Flowering: April–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Sukhothai (Ramkhamhaeng), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang), Nakhon Sawan (Tham Phet-Tham Thong); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Si Than); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan), Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri; PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Lamae), Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Satun, Songkhla.
distribution: Nicobar Islands, Andaman Islands (type), Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra.
ecology: Sand dunes, coastal heath forests, lower tropical rain forests, seasonal evergreen forests, lower mixed deciduous forests, scrub, bamboo thickets, old clearings and in crevices of exposed rocks (especially limestone); 0–400(–1,200) m alt. Flowering: mainly March–June, but also recorded in January and November.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Sam Roi Yot – type: Larsen 74-00095, holotype -AAU, isotype -C).

ecology: Lower montane to montane evergreen forests, epiphyte or lithophyte; 900–1,600 m alt. Flowering: March–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Wong); NORTH EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Soi Dao), Trat.
distribution: India, Nepal, Myanmar, Tibet, Laos, Vietnam, China, Peninsular Malaysia (type), Sumatra, Borneo.
ecology: Lowland to lower montane forests, also on limestone outcrops; 380–1,700 m alt. Flowering: October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai (Mae Suai), Nan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); SOUTH EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat.
distribution: Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia (type), Sumatra, Borneo.
ecology: Lowland to lower montane forests, also on limestone outcrops; 300–1,850 m alt. Flowering: October–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Dan Sai); EASTERN: Si Sa Ket (Khao Phra Wihan); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Soi Dao).
ecology: Deciduous forests, flowers in the dry season; 200–300 m alt. Flowering: April–June, October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Hin Rong Kla – type: Tippayasri et al. 183, holotype -BKF, isotypes -BK QBG).
ecology: Lower montane evergreen forests. Epiphyte on (small) trees and lithophyte on moss-covered sandstone rock platforms; 1,100–2,100 m alt. Flowering: August–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai (Wiang Pa Pao), Phayao (Phu Langka), Nan (Doi Phukha), Tak (Doi Musoe), Phitsanulok (Phu Miang); NORTH EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Phu Khiao), Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Soi Dao Nuea).
distribution: India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar, Vietnam, China.
ecology: Montane evergreen forests; 700–2,150 m alt. Flowering: March, May–August, December.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha).
ecology: On trunks and major branches of trees in lowland forests and lower montane forests; 275–1,500 m alt. Flowering: mostly in October–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Lom Sak); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Tha Khanun); PENINSULAR: Ranong.
ecology: Epiphyte in hill evergreen forests; 400–1,000 m alt. Flowering: January–May.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani, Yala.
ecology: Lower and medium montane evergreen forests, sometimes lithophytic or terrestrial; 1,000–1,800 m alt. Flowering: December–February and May–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak, Nakhon Sawan (Khao Pado); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Nong).
ecology: Lower and medium montane evergreen forests, sometimes lithophytic or terrestrial; 900–1,800 m alt. Flowering: December–February and May–September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Narathiwat (Su-ngai Padi).
distribution: Malaysia (Peninsular and Borneo), Singapore, Indonesia (type), the Philippines.
ecology: Evergreen lowland to lower montane forests; 0–1,500 m alt. Flowering all year long, mostly in October–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Tak.
ecology: Lowland, hill and ridge forests; 200–1,200 m alt. Flowering: May–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Doi Chik Chong), Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phayao, Nan, Tak (Doi Musoe), Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Phu Khieo); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; PENINSULAR: Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha), Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar, Vietnam, China.
ecology: Montane evergreen forests; 800–2,500 m alt. Flowering: February–July, October.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Peninsular and Bornean Malaysia, W Indonesia (type), Brunei Darussalam.
ecology: Lowland evergreen forests, on trunks and major branches of trees and shrubs, also in wetlands and along streams, sometimes terrestrial; 0–900 m alt. Flowering: February–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Si Sawat).
ecology: Epiphyte in evergreen forests; 400–600 m alt. Flowering: April–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Ma Pha), Chiang Mai (Fang), Tak (Ban Musoe – type: Seidenfaden & Smitinand GT 7379, holotype -C); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Suan Sai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
ecology: Dry hill forests; 550–850 m alt. Flowering: March, July–August.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang), Pattani (Khao Kalakhiri), Yala.
ecology: Montane evergreen forests or lithophyte on mossy rocks and steep limestone cliffs; 1,100–2,100 m alt. Flowering all year long, mostly March–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Ma Pha), Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lamphun, Lampang, Tak, Phitsanulok, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Nakhon Phanom (Huai Kok); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Chulabhorn dam), Ubon Ratchathani (Pha Taem); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Sabap), Trat; PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Kasom), Trang, Satun (Khuan Don).
distribution: India, Myanmar (type), Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java.
ecology: Lowland to lower montane deciduous forests. Epiphyte on tree trunks, sometimes lithophytic on mossy rocks; 100 to 2,000 m alt. Flowering: September–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Wong).
ecology: Epiphyte or lithophyte in hill evergreen forests; exact altitudinal range not recorded. Flowering: October–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chiang Dao).
ecology: Montane forests. Epiphyte on tree trunks, sometimes lithophytic on mossy rocks; 1,700–2,000 m alt. Flowering: May.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang – type: van Beusekom & Phengklai 957, holotype -L, isotypes -BKF C E K P), Pattani (Khao Kalakhiri), Yala (Betong).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lampang, Phitsanulok (Phu Miang); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Wangka); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat (Khao Kuap).
distribution: India (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, China, Peninsular Malaysia.
ecology: Evergreen lowland to lower montane forests, also on limestone; 500–1,700 m alt. Flowering: December–April.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khlong Nakha), Phangnga, Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha), Trang (Khao Sung), Satun (Khao Khiao range).
ecology: Lowland and montane evergreen forests; 700–1,900 m alt. Flowering: March–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Tak, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok.
distribution: NE India, Nepal (type), Bhutan, Myanmar, Vietnam.
ecology: Tropical evergreen forests, hill evergreen forests, 700–1,800 m alt. Flowering: July–October.

thailand: Yala (Betong), Narathiwat.
