thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai; NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (fide Seidenf., Opera Bot. 124: 15. 1995); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (fide S. Suddee); PENINSULAR: Ranong.
ecology: Lithophytic, terrestrial or very rarely epiphytic in deciduous and evergreen forests over limestone, often in rock outcrops; 850–1,950 m alt. Flowering: October–January(–February).

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan, Lampang, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; SOUTH WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri.
ecology: Lithophytic or rarely epiphytic in mixed dry evergreen or deciduous forests over limestone; 200–900 m alt. Flowering: (November–)December–January(–February).

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN or EASTERN: fide Vaddhanaphuti, Wild Orchids Thail., ed. 4: 55. 2005; SOUTH-WESTERN: fide Vaddhanaphuti, op. cit.; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani (photos seen), Phangnga.
distribution: Myanmar (type), Laos, Vietnam, the Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, Borneo, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, Maluku, New Guinea.
ecology: Epiphytic, lithophytic or rarely terrestrial in limestone forests; from sea level to 60 m alt. Flowering: November, January–February.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Si Sa Ket; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun.
distribution: Cambodia, Vietnam, the Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia (syntypes).
ecology: Terrestrial or lithophytic in evergreen forests, mostly over limestone; from sea level to 800 m alt. Flowering: (December–)January–February.

thailand: EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP – type: Put 3497, holotype -BK, isotypes -C K); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; UNSPECIFIED: Khao Yai NP [comprising parts of the provinces of Nakhon Ratchasima, Saraburi, Prachin Buri, Nakhon Nayok].
ecology: Terrestrial in forests; 1,300–2,000 m alt. Flowering: December–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
ecology: Normally terrestrial or lithophytic in dry evergreen forests, once reported as an epiphyte; 550–1,200 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Hosseus 249, holotype -M, isotype -P), Nan (fide Seidenf. & Smitinand, Orchids Thail.: 338. 1961), Uttaradit, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH EASTERN: Prachin Buri; PENINSULAR: ?Ranong‒Surat Thani area, Phangnga.
ecology: Terrestrial, lithophytic or very rarely epiphytic in evergreen and deciduous forests over sandstone or granite; 300–1,640 m alt. Flowering: (September–)October–December(–April).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla, Yala.
distribution: Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo.
ecology: Terrestrial, the habitat was not recorded in Thailand but in other parts of the distribution area the species is found in lowland and hill evergreen rainforests; to 1,100 m alt. Flowering: September–November.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (photos seen), Yala (Hala Bala WS – Poopath 369 -BKF).
distribution: Vietnam, S China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: Terrestrial in mountain forests; the only known Thai herbarium specimen was collected at 1,440 m alt. Flowering: September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha NP – type: Williams 1955 -A).
ecology: Terrestrial, the Thai specimen was collected in lower montane forests, at 1,200 m alt. It was found in flower in June.

thailand: PENINSULAR (fide Vaddhanaphuti, Wild Orchids Thail., ed. 4: 53. 2005).
distribution: S China, Taiwan, S Japan, the Philippines, Borneo, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: Terrestrial. Habitat not recorded in Thailand, but in other parts of the distribution area the species is found in medium to high altitudes forests. Flowering: July– November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani.
distribution: NE India (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen and deciduous forests over granite, often near streams; 700‒1,400 m alt. Flowering: November–December(–January), occasionally also in April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (photos seen); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei.
distribution: Nepal, Bhutan, NE India (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan, S Japan.
ecology: Terrestrial in mixed forests; 1,350–1,530 m alt. Flowering: (August–)October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak, Phitsanulok.
distribution: NE India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan, Japan.
ecology: Terrestrial in hill evergreen forests; 1,300–2,100 m alt. Flowering: April, September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei.
distribution: Nepal, NE India (type), Bhutan, Myanmar, SW China.
ecology: Terrestrial, habitat not recorded in Thailand but elsewhere the species is found in mountain forests and thickets near streams; 1,460–1,550 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type: Put 4470, holotype -K).
ecology: Terrestrial in open limestone terrain in savanna or forests; 1,700–2,000 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (cultivated, from Amphoe Nam Yuen – Thavipoke s.n. KKU); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Krabi, Pattani, Narathiwat.

ecology: Terrestrial in montane forests in deep shade near streams; 1,700−2,100 m alt. Flowering: June–August.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Khao Phanom Bencha NP – type: Williams 1955 -A).
ecology: Terrestrial, the Thai specimen was collected in lower montane forests, at 1,200 m alt. It was found in flower in June.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (photos seen), Yala (Hala Bala WS – Poopath 369 -BKF).
distribution: Vietnam, S China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Sumatra, Java (type).

ecology: Terrestrial, habitat not recorded in Thailand but elsewhere the species is found in mountain forests and thickets near streams; 1,460–1,550 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Hosseus 249, holotype -M, isotype -P), Nan (fide Seidenf. & Smitinand, Orchids Thail.: 338. 1961), Uttaradit, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH EASTERN: Prachin Buri; PENINSULAR: ?Ranong‒Surat Thani area, Phangnga.
ecology: Terrestrial, lithophytic or very rarely epiphytic in evergreen and deciduous forests over sandstone or granite; 300–1,640 m alt. Flowering: (September–)October–December(–April).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Krabi, Pattani, Narathiwat.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen rainforests over limestone; 75–400 m alt. Flowering: March, August–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani.
distribution: NE India (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen and deciduous forests over granite, often near streams; 700‒1,400 m alt. Flowering: November–December(–January), occasionally also in April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (photos seen); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei.
distribution: Nepal, Bhutan, NE India (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan, S Japan.
ecology: Terrestrial in mixed forests; 1,350–1,530 m alt. Flowering: (August–)October–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Phahompok – Suksathan 4808 -QBG), Nan (photos seen).
distribution: NE India (type), Myanmar, Vietnam, S & SW China.
ecology: Terrestrial in montane forests in deep shade near streams; 1,700−2,100 m alt. Flowering: June–August.

thailand: EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP – type: Put 3497, holotype -BK, isotypes -C K); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; UNSPECIFIED: Khao Yai NP [comprising parts of the provinces of Nakhon Ratchasima, Saraburi, Prachin Buri, Nakhon Nayok].
ecology: Terrestrial in forests; 1,300–2,000 m alt. Flowering: December–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai; NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (fide Seidenf., Opera Bot. 124: 15. 1995); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (fide S. Suddee); PENINSULAR: Ranong.
ecology: Lithophytic, terrestrial or very rarely epiphytic in deciduous and evergreen forests over limestone, often in rock outcrops; 850–1,950 m alt. Flowering: October–January(–February).

thailand: EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (cultivated, from Amphoe Nam Yuen – Thavipoke s.n. KKU); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
ecology: Not known. Flowering: December (in cultivation).

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (fide Seidenf., Dansk Bot. Ark. 29(2): 20. 1975), Nan, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; PENINSULAR: Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: India, Sri Lanka, Nepal (type), Bhutan, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan, Japan, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, Lesser Sunda Islands, Borneo, Sulawesi.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen and scrub forests; 150–1,500 m alt. Flowering: March, (June–)August–September, also recorded in December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat.
distribution: NE India (type), Bhutan, Bangladesh, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, S & SW China.
ecology: Terrestrial in open dipterocarp and pine forests and in grasslands, often in marshy places; 850–1,100 m alt. Flowering: May–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak, Phitsanulok.
distribution: NE India (type), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, China, Taiwan, Japan.
ecology: Terrestrial in hill evergreen forests; 1,300–2,100 m alt. Flowering: April, September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla, Yala.
distribution: Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo.
ecology: Terrestrial, the habitat was not recorded in Thailand but in other parts of the distribution area the species is found in lowland and hill evergreen rainforests; to 1,100 m alt. Flowering: September–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan, Lampang, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun; SOUTH WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri.
ecology: Lithophytic or rarely epiphytic in mixed dry evergreen or deciduous forests over limestone; 200–900 m alt. Flowering: (November–)December–January(–February).

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Si Sa Ket; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun.
distribution: Cambodia, Vietnam, the Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia (syntypes).
ecology: Terrestrial or lithophytic in evergreen forests, mostly over limestone; from sea level to 800 m alt. Flowering: (December–)January–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type: Put 4470, holotype -K).
ecology: Terrestrial in open limestone terrain in savanna or forests; 1,700–2,000 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: PENINSULAR (fide Vaddhanaphuti, Wild Orchids Thail., ed. 4: 53. 2005).
distribution: S China, Taiwan, S Japan, the Philippines, Borneo, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java (type).
ecology: Terrestrial. Habitat not recorded in Thailand, but in other parts of the distribution area the species is found in medium to high altitudes forests. Flowering: July– November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
ecology: Normally terrestrial or lithophytic in dry evergreen forests, once reported as an epiphyte; 550–1,200 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand

NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN or EASTERN: fide Vaddhanaphuti, Wild Orchids Thail., ed. 4: 55. 2005; SOUTH-WESTERN: fide Vaddhanaphuti, op. cit.; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani (photos seen), Phangnga.
distribution: Myanmar (type), Laos, Vietnam, the Philippines, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, Borneo, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, Maluku, New Guinea.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Thung Salaeng Luang NP – type: Seidenfaden & Smitinand GT 5603, holotype -C [spirit]), Loei; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (fide Seidenf., Opera Bot. 89: 49. 1986 [as Phaius indigoferus ]); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Phangnga (fide Seidenf., op. cit.; identification uncertain, fruiting [as P. indigoferus ]), Pattani.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (fide Seidenf., Opera Bot. 89: 58. 1986); PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani (fide Seidenf., op. cit.), Phangnga, Krabi (photos seen), Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Trang, Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Taiwan, S Japan, the Philippines, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, Maluku, New Guinea, Bismarck Archipelago, Solomon Islands, NE Australia (Queensland), Caroline Islands, Vanuatu, New Caledonia, Fiji, Samoa, Tonga, Santa Cruz Islands, Marianas. Naturalised in Kenya, the Seychelles, Nauru Islands, Hawaii, Florida, several Caribbean Islands.
ecology: Terrestrially in evergreen lowland or hill forests over shale and granite and in disturbed sites like road cuttings or building ruins, 200–1,300 m alt. Flowering: October–August.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala (Hala Bala WS – Middleton et al. 3672B -BKF), Narathiwat (Suksathan, pers. comm.).
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (type), Sumatra, Java, Borneo, Lesser Sunda Islands, Sulawesi, ?New Guinea.
ecology: Terrestrial, habitat unknown, 1,490 m alt. Flowering: May.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Niyomdham 8689 -BKF).
ecology: Not known in Thailand. In Borneo terrestrial among rocks under bamboo in hill and lower montane forests at 800–1,700 m alt. (Wood & Cribb 1994), in Peninsular Malaysia at about 900 m (Seidenfaden & Wood 1992). Flowering: time not known.

NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Nan, Phitsanulok; NORTH EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Udon Thani (Nong Saeng); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Kaeng Krachan); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Phatthalung (Khao Pu-Khao Ya).
distribution: India (syntypes), Bhutan, SE Tibet, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, S China (Yunnan, Guangxi), Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, the Philippines.
ecology: Shaded areas in tropical rain forests, hill evergreen forests, seasonal evergreen forests and mixed deciduous forests, 100–1,700 m alt. Flowering: mainly August–September, but also recorded in July and December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Tak (Mae Moei), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang), Nakhon Sawan (Ban Chum Saeng); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Namtok Phlio); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Ban Racha Krude), Phangnga, Krabi, Trang (Huai Yot), Songkhla (Khlong Hoi Khong), Yala (Betong).
distribution: Insufficiently known, usually indicated to include India, Indo China, S China, Taiwan, Malesia (excluding the Philippines and Maluku), N Australia, New Caledonia.
ecology: In tropical rain forests, hill evergreen forests and seasonal evergreen forests, rarely in deciduous forests, 0–1,300 m alt. Flowering: February–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak, Nakhon Sawan (Ban Chum Saeng); NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen (Nam Phong); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Surin; SOUTH WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Kaeng), Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Mueang District), Trang (Sikao).
distribution: Insufficiently known, usually indicated to include India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Laos, and all major parts of Malesia.
ecology: In hill evergreen forests, seasonal evergreen forests, lower mixed deciduous forests, dry deciduous dipterocarp forests and bamboo thickets, rarely in pine forests and rubber plantations, 50–1,400 m alt. Flowering: mainly May–September, but also recorded in February and April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Nan, Phitsanulok; NORTH EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Udon Thani (Nong Saeng); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Kaeng Krachan); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Phatthalung (Khao Pu-Khao Ya).
distribution: India (syntypes), Bhutan, SE Tibet, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Vietnam, S China (Yunnan, Guangxi), Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, the Philippines.
ecology: Shaded areas in tropical rain forests, hill evergreen forests, seasonal evergreen forests and mixed deciduous forests, 100–1,700 m alt. Flowering: mainly August–September, but also recorded in July and December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Tak (Mae Moei), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang), Nakhon Sawan (Ban Chum Saeng); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Namtok Phlio); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Ban Racha Krude), Phangnga, Krabi, Trang (Huai Yot), Songkhla (Khlong Hoi Khong), Yala (Betong).
distribution: Insufficiently known, usually indicated to include India, Indo China, S China, Taiwan, Malesia (excluding the Philippines and Maluku), N Australia, New Caledonia.
ecology: In tropical rain forests, hill evergreen forests and seasonal evergreen forests, rarely in deciduous forests, 0–1,300 m alt. Flowering: February–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak, Nakhon Sawan (Ban Chum Saeng); NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen (Nam Phong); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Surin; SOUTH WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Kaeng), Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Mueang District), Trang (Sikao).
distribution: Insufficiently known, usually indicated to include India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Laos, and all major parts of Malesia.
ecology: In hill evergreen forests, seasonal evergreen forests, lower mixed deciduous forests, dry deciduous dipterocarp forests and bamboo thickets, rarely in pine forests and rubber plantations, 50–1,400 m alt. Flowering: mainly May–September, but also recorded in February and April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan (Mae Charim), Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Tha Khanun – type: Kerr 0261, lectotype -C, isolectotypes -BK K).
ecology: Rheophytic in stream beds, often forming extensive colonies; ca 100–300 m alt. Flowering: January–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai (Mae Sai), Phayao (Ban Pak Bok), Nan (Tham Sakoen), Tak (Umphang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok – type: sine coll. DB 9176, holotype -C).
ecology: In hill evergreen forests and moist upper mixed deciduous forests, 800–1,300 m alt. Flowering: October–November.

NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam), Chiang Mai, Nan (Ban Muang Nan), Lamphun, Lampang, Phrae (Mae Wa), Tak, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan (Takfa); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Udon Thani (Phu Prabat), Nong Khai (Phon Phisai), Sakhon Nakhon, Nakhon Phanom (Ban Dong Bang), Mukdahan (Phu Mano); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Khaeng), Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan); CENTRAL: Saraburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong (Ao Prapat), Surat Thani, Phuket (Namtok Ton Sai), Krabi, Songkhla.
distribution: India (iconotype), Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, S China (Yunnan, Guangdong, Hainan).
ecology: Lower tropical rain forests, lower mixed deciduous forests, moist upper mixed deciduous forests, savanna forests and bamboo thickets, 100–950 m alt. Flowering: mainly April–June, but also recorded in March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Kerr 30, holotype -K, isotype -TCD), Phayao (University of Phayao), Uttaradit (Huai Mun), Tak, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao), Loei (Phu Kradueng), Mukdahan (Phu Mano), Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Kheng), Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; PENINSULAR: Krabi (Plai Phraya).
ecology: Deciduous forests, savanna forests and open pine forests, 50–1,300 m alt. Flowering: mainly April–May, but also recorded in March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Lamphun (Mae Tha), Tak (Umphang); NORTH EASTERN: Phetchabun (Khao Hin Prakarung); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sangkhla Buri), Ratchaburi (Namtok Kaeo Chan), Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang); CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri (Si Racha); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Krabi, Satun, Songkhla (Ban Prakop), Yala (Betong).
distribution: Bangladesh, Myanmar, Cambodia, Vietnam, Peninsular Malaysia. Type of unknown geographic origin.
ecology: Tropical rain forests, seasonal evergreen forests, lower mixed deciduous forests, moist upper mixed deciduous forests, hill evergreen forests and bamboo thickets; 0–1,000 m alt. Flowering: May–August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Ban Pang Mo), Chiang Mai, Lampang (Thum Chang), Phrae, Tak, Nakhon Sawan (Takfa); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Khao Hin Prakarung), Loei (Phu Pha Man); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi, Phetchaburi (Khao Yoi), Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Saraburi (Sam Lan); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Trat (Ko Kut); PENINSULAR: Ranong, Yala (Banang Sata).
distribution: Sri Lanka, India (iconotype), Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Cambodia, Vietnam, S China, Taiwan, Ryukyus and throughout Malesia to N & W Australia and the W Pacific Islands (south-east to Niue).
ecology: Lower mixed deciduous forests, moist upper deciduous forests, bamboo thickets, rubber plantations and secondary growths in old clearings of lower tropical rain forests, 0–300 m alt. Flowering: mainly June–July, but also recorded in April and May.

distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (syntypes), Sumatra, Mentawi, Bangka, Borneo, Sulawesi, ?the Philippines.
ecology: Moist to swampy areas in lower tropical rain forests; 0–300 m alt. Flowering: recorded in January, May, June and August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Chongdong), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang), Trang (Huai Yot).

ecology: Terrestrial in hill evergreen forests, freshwater swamp forests, seasonal evergreen forests and bamboo thickets; 700–1,750 m alt. Flowering: mainly May–August, but also recorded in January, March, April, September and October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Hin Rong Kla); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ban Don).

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Hin Rong Kla); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang).
ecology: Montane forests; 1,100–1,500 m alt. Flowering: July–August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Hin Rong Kla); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang).
ecology: Montane forests; 1,100–1,500 m alt. Flowering: July–August.

ecology: Terrestrial or occasionally lithophytic in open, grassy evergreen or deciduous forests with Dipterocarpaceae, Lauraceae, Ericaceae, Fagaceae and

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala (Betong – Atdhabhan 110902 -QBG).
distribution: From Peninsular Malaysia across Java (type), Borneo and Maluku to the Philippines in the north-east and New Guinea and the Solomon Islands in the south-east.
ecology: The only known population in Thailand grows in a shaded marshy area in lower tropical rain forests, ca 500 m alt. Flowering: October.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Songkhla, Pattani, Yala.
distribution: Vietnam, Andaman Islands, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, Java (type), Borneo.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen forests, 50–700 m alt. Flowering: April, July– August.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla.
distribution: Andaman Islands, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Sumatra, Borneo (type), Maluku, New Guinea.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen forests over limestone, in freshwater swamp forests or rarely in swampy grasslands, 25–300 m alt. Flowering: October–February, April, June–July.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat.
ecology: Terrestrial in evergreen forests, often near waterfalls, 400–500 m alt. Flowering: May–June.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (fide Haniff, Agric. Bull. Straits Fed. Malay States 1(10): 353. 1916; identification uncertain), Narathiwat (Hala Bala Forest – Niyomdham 7189A -BKF).
ecology: Terrestrial, habitat not recorded in Thailand but in Peninsular Malaysia and Singapore found in lowland forests. Flowering: February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan; SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat; UNSPECIFIED: Khao Yai NP [comprising parts of the provinces of Nakhon Ratchasima, Saraburi, Prachin Buri and Nakhon Nayok].

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Trang (Khao Chong), Satun, Songkhla, Narathiwat.
distribution: Myanmar, Cambodia, Malaysia (Peninsular, Sabah, Sarawak), Brunei, Indonesia (Java (type), Kalimantan, Sumatra, Sulawesi), the Philippines.
ecology: Epiphyte or lithophyte growing among mosses along streams and in moist, shaded areas in evergreen forests, 50–1,200 m alt. Also found in limestone forests. Sometimes becoming locally abundant. Flowering throughout the year.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala (Betong).
ecology: Growing as an epiphyte on mossy tree trunks in lower montane forests, ca 1,050 m alt. Flowering: June–August.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong (Khlong Kam Puan), Surat Thani, Phangnga, Nakhon Si Thammarat (Wat Khiriwong), Satun (Ko Tarutao), Yala, Narathiwat.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani (Gunung Ina – Kerr 077 -K).
ecology: Growing as an epiphyte in evergreen forests, 1,100 m alt. Flowering: August.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Chiang Mai.
ecology: Epiphytic in lower montane rain forests, 1,500–1,600 m alt. Flowering: May–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (“Omkoi road at km 12”), Tak (Mae Tuen – type: Kerr 484, holotype -K); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thong Pha Phum).

ecology: Terrestrial on sand, clay or humus-rich soil, sometimes on mossy rocks or in leaf-litter on rocks, tolerates both open and shaded habitats (e.g. grassy road sides, forests edges and wet stream banks in forests). Tropical rain forests, bamboo thickets and hill evergreen forests, 0–2,000 m alt. Flowering: June–July.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom (That Phanom); EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (Chanuman).
ecology: Banks of rivers, 200–300 m alt. Flowering: July–September.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand

NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Sop Ap to Pha Mon, Doi Suthep, Doi Chang, Doi Chiang Dao, Wang Tao, Pha Hom Pok), Chiang Rai (Ban San Sa At), Lampang (16 km N of Tak), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP), Tak (Lansang NP, Ban Musoe); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng, Phu Luang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom to Thung Kramang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan); CENTRAL: Saraburi (to Pak Chong); Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Pota Luang Kaeo), Surat Thani (Chong Lom), Trang (Khao Chong Botanic Garden).
distribution: Native from E Asian tropics (Sumatra – type), Malaysia northward Japan.
ecology: On soils derived from limestones and sandstones in deciduous forests, bamboo thickets to open hill evergreen forests with pines-oaks, 0–1,900 m alt. Flowering all year round.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Muang Khu, Doi Chiang Dao, Fang, Mae Klang Luang), Lampang (Chae Son), Tak (Huai Krasa); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Lomkao, Phu Miang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom), Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP, Khao Laem).
ecology: Grassy slopes in old clearings of hill evergreen or light forests, 350–1,200 m alt. Flowering: probably all the year round.

thailand: NORTHRN: Chiang Mai (Mae Hoi, Mae Klang), Chiang Rai (Wat Tham Sao Hin Phayanak, Mae Sai), Lampang (Doi Khun Tan); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Kaeng Sopha Falls, Thung Salaeng Luang NP, Nakhonthai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Muang Kao, Sai Yok, Thong Pha Phum), Ratchaburi (Pak Tawan); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khok Samrong), Saraburi (Muak Lek), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Chakan Arboretum), Chon Buri (Si Racha).
distribution: Tropical Africa, Sri Lanka, India (Madras, New Delhi – type), Myanmar, Cambodia, Vietnam, and scattered through C & S America.
ecology: Waysides near swamps, old rice fields or open grassy slopes in deciduous forests on limestone hills, 10–900 m alt. Flowering: December–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chiang Dao), Lampang (Ban Tha Tosak); NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen (Phu Wiang).
distribution: India, China (Yunnan), Laos, Vietnam, the Philippines, Australia, New Caledonia (type).
ecology: Dry grassy slopes in open secondary vegetation, and dipterocarp forests, 300 m alt. Flowering: January–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mapha), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Huai Pong), Loei (Sam Hak, Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Katatak).
distribution: Sri Lanka, India, Nepal (type), Bhutan, China (Yunnan), Vietnam, Cambodia, the Philippines, Indonesia (Java).
ecology: Common in oak-pine forests, 400–1,000 m alt. Flowering: December–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Muang Sroi), Chiang Mai (Ban Yang, Dong Tak Tent & Chom Thong to Mae Wang, Doi Inthanon, Doi Suthep), Tak (Li, 50th Ranger Station); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Dan Sai, Kao Keo Kang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang).
ecology: Roadsides, grassy fields, on dry ground in open forests, 300–1,600 m alt. Flowering: February–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mapha), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Huai Pong), Loei (Sam Hak, Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Katatak).
distribution: Sri Lanka, India, Nepal (type), Bhutan, China (Yunnan), Vietnam, Cambodia, the Philippines, Indonesia (Java).
ecology: Common in oak-pine forests, 400–1,000 m alt. Flowering: December–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Muang Sroi), Chiang Mai (Ban Yang, Dong Tak Tent & Chom Thong to Mae Wang, Doi Inthanon, Doi Suthep), Tak (Li, 50th Ranger Station); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Dan Sai, Kao Keo Kang); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang).
ecology: Roadsides, grassy fields, on dry ground in open forests, 300–1,600 m alt. Flowering: February–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mapha, Pai), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Mae Pau, Mae Klang Falls, Ban Yang, Doi Chiang Dao, Ban Mae Chia, Ban Mae Kon, Ping Khong, Bo Luang, Doi Saket, Mae Sanam), Lamphun (Li), Tak (Raheng); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Dan Sai), Sakon Nakhon, Mukdahan (Khamcha-e); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom, Thung Kamang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthaithani (Khao Nang Ram Research Station).
ecology: Grassy slopes in open dipterocarp forests, mixed deciduous forests, and open pine forests, 250–1,600 m alt. Flowering: November–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Lampang (Huai Tak, Ban Mae Ta), Tak (Ban Phu Pae); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thung Ma Ho to Kaeng Khaep).
ecology: Sandy beds and banks of rivers, 300–600 m alt. Flowering: April–May.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Sam Roi Yot); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Samut Prakan (Bang Pakong, Bang Pu Kao, Ban Khlong Ta Wai), Nakhon Pathom (Nakhon Chaisi), Samut Sakhon (Ban Khlong Su); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Bang Pa Ken), Trat (Ko Chang, Klong); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Kao Mut), Phuket (Thalang, Ko Yao Yai, Nai Han Beach).
distribution: India (type), Myanmar, China (Yunnan, Guizhou), the Philippines, Vietnam (Saigon), Malaysia (Malacca), Indonesia.
ecology: Open areas in mangrove, evergreen forests and in old clearings, 0–50 m alt. Flowering: August–March, perhaps all year round.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Lampang (Huai Tak, Ban Mae Ta), Tak (Ban Phu Pae); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thung Ma Ho to Kaeng Khaep).
ecology: Sandy beds and banks of rivers, 300–600 m alt. Flowering: April–May.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan (Sam Roi Yot); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok), Samut Prakan (Bang Pakong, Bang Pu Kao, Ban Khlong Ta Wai), Nakhon Pathom (Nakhon Chaisi), Samut Sakhon (Ban Khlong Su); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Bang Pa Ken), Trat (Ko Chang, Klong); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Kao Mut), Phuket (Thalang, Ko Yao Yai, Nai Han Beach).
distribution: India (type), Myanmar, China (Yunnan, Guizhou), the Philippines, Vietnam (Saigon), Malaysia (Malacca), Indonesia.
ecology: Open areas in mangrove, evergreen forests and in old clearings, 0–50 m alt. Flowering: August–March, perhaps all year round.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mapha, Pai), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Mae Pau, Mae Klang Falls, Ban Yang, Doi Chiang Dao, Ban Mae Chia, Ban Mae Kon, Ping Khong, Bo Luang, Doi Saket, Mae Sanam), Lamphun (Li), Tak (Raheng); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Dan Sai), Sakon Nakhon, Mukdahan (Khamcha-e); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom, Thung Kamang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthaithani (Khao Nang Ram Research Station).
ecology: Grassy slopes in open dipterocarp forests, mixed deciduous forests, and open pine forests, 250–1,600 m alt. Flowering: November–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon), Nan (Ban Tai); NORTH- EASTERN: Loei (Na Haeo); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Laem); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Bo Noi); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Bo Rai, Khao Sabap); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Paknam, Thako), Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Surat Thani, Krabi (Khao Panom), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang, Yong Falls), Pattani (Betong), Narathiwat (Sirindhorn Falls, Bacho).
distribution: China (Hainan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Guangxi, Hong Kong, Taiwan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Penang, Sabah), Singapore, Indonesia (Sumatra, Java, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, Maluku, West Irian Jaya, Papua), the Philippines (Luzon, Mindanao, Mindoro, Negros, Palawan, Samar, Surigao, Sulu), Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia.
ecology: Edges or interior of open evergreen forests by streams to mountains, 50–1,500 m alt. Flowering: October–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Chiang Dao), Lampang (Doi Khun Tan, Doi Luang NP), Phrae; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nong Bua Daeng, Khao Phaya); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Huai Klity, Song Tho), Ratchaburi (Wangka, Bang Saphan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Huai Sai Falls, Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Surat Thani (Song Phi Nong), Phuket, Krabi (Khao Phanom), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang, Khiriwong).
distribution: China (Guangdong, Taiwan), Japan (Ryukyu), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Malaysia (Sarawak), Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatra, Java), the Philippines (Leyte, Luzon, Mindanao, Mindoro, Negros, Samar), Australia (Christmas Island).
ecology: Small ravines by streams or clearings in open evergreen forests, 100–1,500 m alt. Flowering: November–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Suthep, Ban Angka Noi, Chom Thong, Pha Hom Pok, SW of Doi Chang), Tak (Huai Krasa, Mae Sot); NORTH- EASTERN: Loei (Si Than); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH- EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Pong Nam Ron), Trat (Ko Chang); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Khaeng), Kanchanaburi (Klang Dong), Ratchaburi (Bang Saphan); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo, Praphat beach), Trang (Khao Phap Pha, Khao Chong NP), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: China (Hainan, Tibet, Yunnan, Guizhou, Taiwan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Sabah, Sarawak), Singapore, Brunei, Indonesia (Borneo, Sumatra, Celebes, Java, Moluccas), the Philippines (Luzon, Leyte, Mindanao, Negros, Palawan, Sulu, Tawi-Tawi), Timor-Leste (Dili), Australia (Christmas Island).
ecology: Old clearings or clearings near villages, at roadsides, on dry slopes in deciduous forests or in open evergreen forests and in mixed bamboo thickets, 120–1,400 m alt. Flowering all year round.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo).
distribution: Borneo, Indonesia (Merapi – type, Java), New Guinea.
ecology: Open lowland and hill evergreen forests with bamboo thickets, 400–1,000 m alt. Flowering: December–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Doi Suthep; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo).
distribution: Nepal Himalaya (type from the valleys between Nepal and Noakote), N India, Bhutan, Myanmar, China (Hainan, Taiwan, Tibet, Guangdong, Guizhou, Guangxi, Yunnan), Taiwan, the Philippines, Indochina, Malaysia, Indonesia.
ecology: Clearings in open evergreen forests, 475–1,900 m alt. Flowering: October–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Doi Chang, Muang Khu to Huai Thak, Doi Chong, Doi Khun Huai Pong), Nan (Ban Thin), Tak (Doi Pae Poe); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khao Kamphaeng, Pilok); PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Khao Bangto), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: China (Yunnan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Malaysia (Penang), Indonesia (Sumatra, Java), the Philippines (Negros), New Caledonia.
ecology: Grassy slopes in evergreen forests, on waste slopes in old clearings or in open spaces of bamboo thickets, 1,000–1,800 m alt. Flowering: October–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Bo Luang, Fang, Ban Kao, Meping); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Kamtakla); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang).
distribution: India (Negapatam, Bengal – type), Bhutan, China (Yunnan), Vietnam.
ecology: Dry and open places with sandy soil or sandy waysides, from sea level to 1,700 m alt. Flowering: October–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam, Ban Huai Hi, Pai, Mo Paeng Falls), Chiang Mai (Khun Khong, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Doi Suthep, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Angka, Mae Klang Falls, Ban Yang, Doi Inthanon, Mae Pau, Sop Ap, Mae Hoi, Mae Chia-Ban, Mae Kon, Doi Chang, Mae Sanam, Omkoi, Maelit Bridge, Mae Pan Falls, Mae Sao Watershed Management Station), Chiang Rai (Doi Phacho, Chiang Khan), Lampang (Huai Maesan, Khun Tan NP, Chae Son NP), Nan (Pha Sing), Tak (Khao Phra Wo, Raheng, Umphang); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP, Thung Salaeng Luang NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng, Phu Luang), Nong Khai (Sangkhom), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP), Nakhon Phanom, Mukdahan (Dongman, Phu Mu NP), Khon Kaen (Mo Din Daeng, Phu Wiang NP, Phu Ta Ka, Wiang Kao); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Huai Pathao, Phu Khiao), Nakhon Ratchasima (Nong Phakchi, Khao Yai NP), Ubon Ratchathani (Chong Mek); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Kaeng WS); Kanchanaburi (Huai Bankao, Thong Phaphum); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Ko Kho Khao).
distribution: Pakistan, India (Eastern India – type, Bengal, Mysore), Nepal (type of
ecology: Dry grassy slopes in old clearings, mixed deciduous and dipterocarp forests, pine-oak forests, 450–1,800 m alt. Flowering: November–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Ang Khang), Tak (Lan Sang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thong Pha Phum NP); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Nakhon Nayok Falls); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Bang Son), Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Surat Thani.
distribution: China (Guangdong), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Peninsular), Indonesia (Java, Sulawesi, Sumbawa, West Timor, Flores).
ecology: Along roads, edges of dry evergreen forests, bamboo thickets on limestone, 400–1,100 m alt. Flowering: November–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai WS, Mo Paeng Falls, Mae Sariang, Huai Hi), Chiang Mai (Doi Chang, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Doi Mae Ya, Doi Pui, Doi Suthep, Mae Taman Reforestation Unit, Bo Luang, Pha Hom Pok, Muang to Yang, Ban Mae Khon, Mae Sanam, Hot, Mae Sao Watershed Management Station, Om Koi, Pine Improvement Centre, Fang to Chiang Rai along route 109, Doi Ruea Wuak), Chiang Rai (Chiang Khan, Pang Kia, Mae Sai, Doi Tung, Ban Hua Suek), Lampang (Ban Mae Thak, Huai Maesan, Hangchat, Doi Khun Tan, Mae Tha), Phrae (Huai Rong, Den Chai), Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Pha Daeng Cliff, Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng, Phu Luang), Nakhon Phanom (Dongman), Mukdahan; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Khiao to Wang Takrai Falls, Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Ma Di river area, Huai Kha Khaeng WS); Kanchanaburi (Huai Lam Ton to Erawan Falls); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri (Nong Yai Bu, Sri Racha).
distribution: China (Hainan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Guizhou, Guangxi, Hong Kong), India (type), Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar, Indochina.
ecology: Among grasses in oak forests, humus-rich slopes in open hill evergreen, mixed deciduous, dry dipterocarp forests, clearings in limestone areas, 200–1,600 m alt. Flowering: October–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep), Chiang Rai (Ban Hua Suek).
ecology: Marshy savanna, 900–1,300 m alt. Flowering: December–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Khun Khong), Chiang Rai.
distribution: China (Yunnan, Taiwan), India, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia (Sumatra).
ecology: Occurring in grasslands, in shady places, to 1,100 m alt. Flowering: March–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Muang Sroi Falls), Chiang Mai (Doi Mae Ya, Doi Suthep Pui NP, Mae Sao Watershed Management Station), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Tak (Doi Pha Hom); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Luang, Phu Thong), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Song Tho, Thong Phaphum to Pilok), Ratchaburi (Bang Saphan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Phrabat, Khitchakut NP, Khao Soi Dao North); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Chongdong), Phangnga (Takuapa, Naichong).
distribution: China (Hainan, Guangdong, Hong Kong), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Penang, Sabah), Indonesia (Borneo, Sumatra, Celebes, Java), the Philippines (Luzon, Mindanao).
ecology: By roads in open dry evergreen forests, old clearings along edges of open evergreen forests or by streams in pine and dipterocarp forests, 10–1,300 m alt. Flowering: September–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Khun Khong, Doi Suthep, Summit of Doi Hua Lon, Mae Seuk, Mae Chaem), Chiang Rai.
distribution: China (Hainan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Sichuan, Guizhou, Guangxi, Taiwan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia (Maluku, West Irian Jaya), the Philippines (Luzon, Mindanao).
ecology: Open completely deforestsed hill evergreen forests, deciduous forests, 200–1,900 m alt. Flowering: November–May.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP).
distribution: China (Hainan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Guangxi), India, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia (Sumatra, West Irian Jaya), the Philippines (Luzon).
ecology: Occurring along streams, above 650 m alt. Flowering: January–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mae Sariang, Mo Paeng Falls), Chiang Mai (Ban Angka Noi, Chom Thong, Doi Suthep, Maesa NP, Pha Hom Pok, Om Koi along route 1099, Ban San Bong, San Sai), Chiang Rai (Ban Nong Lu), Lampang (Mae Yom); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Thung Salaeng Luang NP), Loei (Si Than, Phu Kradueng NP); EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (Khemarat); CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo (Khao Chakan Arboretum), Prachin Buri (Chakan Arboretum), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Klang Kamphuam, Kraburi, Bang Yai Falls).
distribution: Africa, Madagascar, Afghanistan, China (Hainan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Sichuan, Guizhou, Guangxi, Hong Kong, Taiwan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Peninsular), Indonesia (Java), the Philippines (Luzon, Mindoro), New Caledonia, Australia (Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia).
ecology: Dry rice fields, on grassy slopes or by open streams in dipterocarp forests, 160–1,400 m alt. Flowering: January–March.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Wa Non); Khon Kaen (Phon); EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani.
distribution: Vietnam and Laos through Malaysia and Indonesia to Papua New Guinea and N Australia.
ecology: In dry dipterocarp forests, usually in clearings on rocky or sandy soil. Also in old rice fields and on saline soils, from sea level to 700 m alt. Flowering: October–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon, Doi Mae Ya, Huai Kaeo Arboretum), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Phrae (Mae Yom NP, Long), Tak (Lan Sang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Thung Salaeng Luang NP, Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng), Khon Kaen (Tham Phothiyan, Phu Khiao); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Katatak, Ban Rai); CENTRAL: Ang Thong; SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong (Ban Pe), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao).
distribution: China (Hainan, Gaungdong, Yunnan, Guangxi, Hong Kong, Taiwan), Japan (Kyushu, Ryukyu), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Peninsular), Indonesia (Java, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, Lombok, Sumbawa, West Timor), the Philippines (Bababac, Culion, Leyte, Luzon, Mindanao, Samar), Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia, Guam.
ecology: A common weed in rice fields and in disturbed areas, from sea level to above 1,900 m alt. Flowering: November–June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai, Huai Yuak, Mo Paeng Falls), Chiang Mai (Ban Mae Kon, Doi Suthep, Fang Hot Spring Park, Mae Sa, Fang, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Suthep), Chiang Rai (Ban Yang Kham Nu), Lampang (Ban Mae Thak to Hang Chat, Huai Mae San); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Luang, Phu Kradueng), Nakhon Phanom (Phu Mu Forest Park), Muk Dahan (Kham Cha-i), Khon Kaen (Nong Waeng, Phaphang Forest Park); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Khaeng WS), Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok Noi, Sai Yok Yai, Erawan NP, Wangka); CENTRAL: Ang Thong, Saraburi (Sam Lan); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri (Chundaten Falls, Khao Yai NP), Chanthaburi (Khitchakut NP, Khlong Narai Falls); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Phangnga (Ko Talibong), Trang (Khao Chong), Songkhla (Boriphat Falls).
distribution: China (Hainan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Taiwan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Malaysia (Peninsular), Indonesia (Kalimantan, Java), New Caledonia.
ecology: Cultivated fields, on humus slopes in deciduous forests or along rocky shores, dry evergreen forests, usually near streams, to 1,500 m alt. Flowering: November–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Mo Paeng Falls), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Huai Kaeo Arboretum, Doi Chiang Dao, Fang Hot Spring Park, Huai Nam Dang, Doi Chang), Chiang Rai (Ban Nong Lu, Doi Tung, Wat Tham Saohin Phayanak, Mae Sai), Lampang (Mae Thak, Doi Khun Tan, Mae Tha distr.), Nan, Phrae (Mae Yom NP, Sahiap, Long), Tak (Rahaeng, Khao Phra Wo), Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Huai Pong, Thung Salaeng Luang NP, Nam Nao NP, Bueng Samphan), Loei (Phu Kradueng, Si Than, Chiang Khan, Ban Na Ao), Nakhon Phanom (Phu Mu Forest Park, Nikhom Khamsoi), Khon Kaen (Phu Wiang); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thung Yai Naresuan, Lai Wo, Ban Sa-ne, Karen Village), Sangkhla, Singkhon Thapo, Sai Yok Yai Falls, Kroengkawia, Thong Phaphum to Pilok), Ratchaburi (Wangka); CENTRAL: Sing Buri, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Chakan Arboretum, Ban Mu Angkao), Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao, Makham), Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo, Praphat beach, Lamliang), Surat Thani (Klong Saeng WS, Chiao Lan Reservoir, Ban Takum), Satun (Khuan Bo).
distribution: China (Hainan), India, Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar, Indochina, Malaysia (Peninsular), Indonesia (Java).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Huai Yuak), Chiang Mai (Fang, Mae Rim to Samoeng Road; Chiang Mai), Chiang Rai (Wat Tham Saohin Phayanak), Lampang (Doi Pang La), Phitsanulok (Bang Rakam), Tak (Lansang NP, Khao Phra Wo); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetachabun (Nam Nao NP); Loei (Phu Kradueng, Ban Wong Wian), Nong Khai (Buengkan; Si Chiang Mai), Khon Kaen (Phaphuang Forest Park, Phothiyan Cave); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Khaeng WS), Kanchanaburi (Sai Yok; Khao Kamphaeng), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan); CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Saraburi (Phu Khae Botanic Garden, Tham Phra Phothisat), Pathum Thani, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok) (Bang Khen – type: Iwatsuki T-254, holotype -KYO, isotypes -BKF TNS; Soi Somprasong), Samut Prakan (Ban Bang Pu Kao), Suphan Buri (U-thong); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri (Khao Yai NP; Chakan Arboretum); PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Su-ngai Kolok).
distribution: A native of the New World tropics, but now widespread in the Old World and introduced in Asia.
ecology: A weed of moist ground and paddy fields, 0–1,000 m alt. Flowering: most of the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pai), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep, Doi Pui, Doi Inthanon, Ban Angka Noi, Bo Luang, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Doi Angka, Doi Pha Kao, Doi Chang), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Tak (Ban Musoe, Huai Mae Lamao); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Phu Miang, Thung Salaeng Luang NP, Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Ruea WS, Phu Kradueng NP), Khon Kaen (Pha Nok Khao); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Thung Kramang), Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Ban Erawan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai NP).
distribution: Widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions (USA – type) of the world, occasionally northward into temperate regions.
ecology: Moist ground at the edges of rice fields, or dry ground along waysides, sunny grassy slopes in secondary oak-pine forests with pine plantations, in dipterocarp forests and rocky ravines of bamboo thickets, 250–1,900 m alt. Flowering: September–January.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Khlong Duea); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Khao Kamphaeng, Bo Phloi).
distribution: Widespread in the tropics and subtropics (USA – type), often a weed of cultivated land.
ecology: Rocky slopes in bamboo thickets and on the ridges of limestone hills in dry evergreen forests, 800–1,500 m alt. Flowering: August–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Pang Bo to Khun Klong, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Bo Luang, Doi Chang); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Thong Stream Bridge near Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Erawan NP, Tham Than Lot NP).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Nakhon Phanom (type of Eriocaulon nakayense : Hayata s.n., holotype -TI), Mukdahan, Kalasin; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (type of E. eglandulatum : Beusekom et al. 4288, holotype -L [255928]; Paratypes: Phengklai & Murata T-42199a -BKF L, Beusekom & Smitinand 2141 -AAU C E GH K L P; Beusekom & Phengklai 2517 -AAU BKF C E GH L P, Sorensen, Larsen & Hansen 6326 -BKF GH L, Charoenphol, Larsen & Warncke 4689 -AAU BKF K L), Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Trang.
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places, on the borders of seasonal ponds or on the borders of barren sandstone rocks, dry dipterocarp forests, 50–1,365 m alt. Flowering: October–March.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Roi Et, Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat (type of Eriocaulon laosense var. maxwellii : Maxwell 74-376, holotype -AAU).
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places, on the borders of seasonal ponds or on the borders of barren sandstone rocks, in paddy fields, dipterocarp forests, 150–210 m alt. Flowering: September–June.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani; EASTERN: Surin; Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat.
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places or paddy fields, 10–500 m alt. Flowering: October–April.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai.
ecology: Open marshy ground and small ponds in bogs, 600–1,000 m alt. Flowering: September–November.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (type: Prajaksood & Suddee 242, holotype -KKU, isotypes -BK BKF K TCD).
ecology: On the borders of seasonal ponds, common on sandy soils in open marshy places or on the borders of barren sandstone rocks, by the side of paths, in pine forests, 1,300 m alt. Flowering: November.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Mukdahan; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (type: Prajaksood & Chantaranothai 89, holotype -KKU, isotypes -BK BKF K TCD).
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places or on the borders of barren sandstone rocks, 150 m alt. Flowering: October–December.

thailand: EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (type: Prajaksood & Chantaranothai 100, holotype -KKU; paratypes: Prajaksood & Suddee 260, 276 & 285 -BK BKF K KKU TCD).
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places or near paddy fields, dipterocarp forests. Flowering: November.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (type: Prajaksood & Chantaranothai 55, holotype -KKU, isotypes -BK BKF K TCD).
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places, dipterocarp forests, 210–600 m alt. Flowering: December–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai; NORTH-EASTERN: Bueng Kan, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (type: Prajaksood & Suddee 299, holotype -KKU, isotypes -BK BKF K TCD).
ecology: On the borders of barren sandstone rocks or sandy soils, in open marshy places, 210–1,000 m alt. Flowering: July–November.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (type: Prajaksood & Chantaranothai 117 holotype -K, isotypes -BK BKF KKU).
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places, pine forests, 1,300 m alt. Flowering: November–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (type of Eriocaulon intermedium var. brevicaule : Shimizu, Huston & Chaiglom T-9035, holotype -KYO, isotypes -BKF C L K), Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Pathum Thani (type of E. intermedium var. glabrum : Tagawa & Iwatsuki T-286, holotype -KYO, isotype -BKF), Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla.
ecology: Submerged on sandy soils in pools, in streams or common on sandy soils in open marshy places, 0–1,300 m alt. Flowering: mostly in October–November.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon, Mukdahan; EASTERN: Ubon Rachathani; SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong, Chanthaburi (type: Smitinand 3679, holotype -NY, isotype -K); PENINSULAR: Trang, Satun.
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places, paddy fields or on the borders of barren sandstone rocks, 5–400 m alt. Flowering: October–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi (type: Sungkhachand 571A, holotype -NY, isotype -K); PENINSULAR: Trang.
ecology: Common on sandy soils in open marshy places, in paddy fields, 10–300 m alt. Flowering: October–January.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat.
ecology: Common on sandy soil in open marshy places and grasslands, 15–400 m alt. Flowering: October–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun, Songkhla, Yala, Narathiwat.
ecology: Various forests types including evergreen, dry deciduous,

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Bueng Kan, Sakon Nakhon, Nakhon Phanom (type: Hayata s.n., holotype -TI); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri.
ecology: Common on open, swampy, marshy places, near streams, in bogs, stagnant water, on sandy soils and moist sandstone, dry deciduous forests, 200–1,400 m alt. Flowering: August–December.

thailand: CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga.
ecology: Common in wet localities, wet paddy fields, seasonal ponds, on mud or sandy soil, 1–130 m alt. Flowering: August–December.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Bueng Kan, Sakon Nakhon, Nakhon Phanom, Mukdahan, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Surin, Si Sa Ket, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Trang.
ecology: Paddy fields, common on sandy soils in open marshy places, on the borders of barren sandstone rocks or on the borders of seasonal ponds, 5–400 m alt. Flowering: September–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai.
ecology: Hill evergreen forests, 1,200 m alt. Fruiting: June–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP), Phitsanulok (Ban Rom Klao, Chattrakan).
distribution: India (Assam), E Pakistan, S China, Taiwan, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, Indonesia (Sumatra), Borneo.
ecology: Hill evergreen forests, 1,000–1,500 m alt. Fruiting: May–July.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP), Phitsanulok (Ban Rom Klao, Chattrakan).
distribution: India (Assam), E Pakistan, S China, Taiwan, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, Indonesia (Sumatra), Borneo.
ecology: Hill evergreen forests, 1,000–1,500 m alt. Fruiting: May–July.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type of Veratrum chiengdaoense : Put 388, Nan (Doi Phu Wae).
distribution: SW China (Yunnan – type, Guizhou, SW Sichuan).
ecology: In thickets, grasslands and forests. Often found in light-open sites in limestone formations, 1,200–4,000 m alt. Flowering: August–January; fruiting: October–January.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nong Bua Lamphu (Nong Bua – type: Kerr 8611, holotype -BM, isotype -BK), Mukdahan, Khon Kaen (Phu Wiang); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Bua Yai).
ecology: Open deciduous forests at ca 200 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Ping rapids at Ban Kao – type: Kerr 3066, type -BM), Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sisawat), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Hua Hin, Khan Kradai, Nong Kae).
ecology: Mixed jungle, 220 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachinburi (Si Racha).
distribution: India (type, probably native only in NE India), Nepal, Bhutan, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam. Cultivated in Malaysia and Indonesia.
ecology: Often planted ornamentally for their fragrant flowers.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Ping rapids at Ban Kao – type: Kerr 3066, type -BM), Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Sisawat), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Hua Hin, Khan Kradai, Nong Kae).
ecology: Mixed jungle, 220 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachinburi (Si Racha).
distribution: India (type, probably native only in NE India), Nepal, Bhutan, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam. Cultivated in Malaysia and Indonesia.
ecology: Often planted ornamentally for their fragrant flowers.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiangdao – type: syntype of Ceratostigma asperrimum Stapf ex Prain: Hosseus 398B -E M; type of C. stapfianum Hosseus: Hosseus 398, holotype -M, isotypes -BM E [2 sheets]).
ecology: Usually common on rocky limestone ridges in the open, also on open spaces (meadows) on slopes with mixed deciduous and evergreen forests, 1,500‒2,120 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: November–March.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Ko Lanta), Satun (Kho Phi, Tarutao NP).
ecology: Mangrove, but perhaps also in the exposed littoral. Flowering: March, July; fruiting: July. Van Steenis (1949) suspects that the fruits are dispersed by floating at sea.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Ban Pong Noi, Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai, Phayao (Doi Luang NP), Lampang (Bang Mai Pao, Doi Khun Tan NP), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Ban Nong Phen), Nakhon Phanom; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Ban Mai, Huai Kha Khaeng Game Reserve), Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao, Mae Nam Noi), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang Falls NP, Kaeng Krachan NP); CENTRAL: Ang Thong (Wat Kiang), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Wat Pakok).
distribution: Widely distributed in the palaeotropics, probably native in SE Asia.
ecology: Often cultivated and escaped, often persistent in abandoned fields and in meadows. Also found in mixed deciduous forests, evergreen forests, dipterocarp forests, bamboo thickets, bedrock shale, limestone, 25‒800 m alt. Flowering: November–February; fruiting specimens are unknown.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chiang Mai University, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Doi Muang Aon, Doi Pui, Sop Hoi), Chiang Rai (Ban Lang Lat, Mae Sai), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Tak, Sukhothai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng, Si Than, Wang Saphung), Sakon Nakhon (Ban Nong Phen); SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi, Phetchaburi (Thung Luang), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan, Kaeng Krachan NP); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Phu Khae Botanical Garden, cultivated); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Makham).
distribution: Widely distributed in the palaeotropics, probably native in SE Asia.
ecology: Often cultivated (gardens) or escaped (e.g., by roadsides), in secondary growths and alluvial thickets in mostly deciduous, very degraded forests, mixed Pinus-dipterocarp forests, in bamboo forests, in clearings to in dense shade, can withstand dry seasonal conditions, bedrock granite, limestone, 100‒1,200 m alt. Flowering throughout the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Ban Pong Noi, Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai, Phayao (Doi Luang NP), Lampang (Bang Mai Pao, Doi Khun Tan NP), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon (Ban Nong Phen), Nakhon Phanom; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Ban Mai, Huai Kha Khaeng Game Reserve), Kanchanaburi (Huai Ban Kao, Mae Nam Noi), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Huai Yang Falls NP, Kaeng Krachan NP); CENTRAL: Ang Thong (Wat Kiang), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Songkhla (Wat Pakok).
distribution: Widely distributed in the palaeotropics, probably native in SE Asia.
ecology: Often cultivated and escaped, often persistent in abandoned fields and in meadows. Also found in mixed deciduous forests, evergreen forests, dipterocarp forests, bamboo thickets, bedrock shale, limestone, 25‒800 m alt. Flowering: November–February; fruiting specimens are unknown.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Chiang Mai University, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Doi Muang Aon, Doi Pui, Sop Hoi), Chiang Rai (Ban Lang Lat, Mae Sai), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Chae Son NP), Tak, Sukhothai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Kradueng, Si Than, Wang Saphung), Sakon Nakhon (Ban Nong Phen); SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi, Phetchaburi (Thung Luang), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Bang Saphan, Kaeng Krachan NP); CENTRAL: Saraburi (Phu Khae Botanical Garden, cultivated); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Makham).
distribution: Widely distributed in the palaeotropics, probably native in SE Asia.
ecology: Often cultivated (gardens) or escaped (e.g., by roadsides), in secondary growths and alluvial thickets in mostly deciduous, very degraded forests, mixed Pinus-dipterocarp forests, in bamboo forests, in clearings to in dense shade, can withstand dry seasonal conditions, bedrock granite, limestone, 100‒1,200 m alt. Flowering throughout the year.

thailand: EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Phu Khiao – type: Pooma 1540, holotype -BKF, isotype -BKF).
ecology: Found along roads in shaded, mixed evergreen forests, 700–1,000 m alt. Flowering: February–May; fruiting: July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Soi, Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon – type of Polyosma elongata : Kerr 5289, holotype -K, isotypes -B BK BM E P TCD); Kamphaeng Phet (Khao Pado); province unknown (Khun Mae Lan, probably Mae Hong Son/Chiang Mai).
ecology: In primary evergreen hardwood and pine forests, along streamlets, over granite bedrock, 1,300–2,000 m alt. Flowering: April–June; fruiting: December–February.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Ko Chang – type of Polyosma arguta : Rabil 7, lectotype -K, isolectotypes -BK BM TCD); PENINSULAR: Chumphon (Langsuan, Tha San), Surat Thani (Klong Nam Wing, Tha Phet, Wangsei, Ko Samui – type of P. bracteolata : Kerr 12561, lectotype -K, isolectotypes -BK BM), Phangnga (Ko Pa, Sri Phangnga), Krabi (Nong Chik), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Tha Samet, Sichon – type of P. oblonga : Kerr 15673, lectotype -K, isolectotypes -BK BM TCD), Trang (Khao Chong), Satun (Khlong Tan, Tarutao Island).
distribution: From the Malay Peninsula through Sumatra and Borneo (type) to the Philippines (Palawan), to be expected in Cambodia, but the published records for Vietnam are doubtful.
ecology: In lowland evergreen forests, along streams, 20–180 m alt. Flowering: January–April; fruiting: April–July. The flowers are fragrant.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khao Nong), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang).
distribution: Indochina, China, W Malesia to the Moluccas and Lesser Sunda Islands (type from Java).
ecology: In wet evergreen forests, hill evergreen forests, shaded or open, 800–1,400 m alt. Flowering: March–May; fruiting: February, May, August. The flowers are very fragrant.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng, Wang Saphung); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai).
ecology: In primary seasonal evergreen forests, along streams, found over sandstone, 800–1,250 m alt. Flowering: January, March–May; fruiting: October, November. The flowers are scented.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khao Nong), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang).
distribution: Indochina, China, W Malesia to the Moluccas and Lesser Sunda Islands (type from Java).
ecology: In wet evergreen forests, hill evergreen forests, shaded or open, 800–1,400 m alt. Flowering: March–May; fruiting: February, May, August. The flowers are very fragrant.

distribution: From the Malay Peninsula through Sumatra and Borneo (type) to the Philippines (Palawan), to be expected in Cambodia, but the published records for Vietnam are doubtful.
ecology: In lowland evergreen forests, along streams, 20–180 m alt. Flowering: January–April; fruiting: April–July. The flowers are fragrant.

ecology: Found along roads in shaded, mixed evergreen forests, 700–1,000 m alt. Flowering: February–May; fruiting: July.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng, Wang Saphung); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai).
ecology: In primary seasonal evergreen forests, along streams, found over sandstone, 800–1,250 m alt. Flowering: January, March–May; fruiting: October, November. The flowers are scented.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Soi, Doi Suthep, Doi Inthanon – type of Polyosma elongata : Kerr 5289, holotype -K, isotypes -B BK BM E P TCD); Kamphaeng Phet (Khao Pado); province unknown (Khun Mae Lan, probably Mae Hong Son/Chiang Mai).
ecology: In primary evergreen hardwood and pine forests, along streamlets, over granite bedrock, 1,300–2,000 m alt. Flowering: April–June; fruiting: December–February.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Doi Khun Huai Pong), Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Suthep, Doi Chiang Dao), Nan (Doi Phukha); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Tha Khanun); PENINSULAR: Phangnga.
distribution: Nepal, India (Assam), Myanmar, S China (Kwangtung, Hainan), Vietnam, Cambodia, Malay Peninsula, Indonesia (type from Java) to the Philippines.
ecology: Often found in light open places e.g. along streams in lowland evergreen forests on the Peninsula or in lower to upper montane rain forests in Northern and North-eastern Thailand.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Kam Phaeng Phet (Mae Wong NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao, Phu Hin Rong Kla NP); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom), Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Laem); SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Khaeng WS), Kanchanaburi (Srisawat, Tham Nam, Sai Yok, Huai Bankao); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Pong Namron, Khlong Pratong).
distribution: N India, Nepal (type), Bhutan, Myanmar, S China, Laos, Vietnam. The Thai records probably represent the southern limit of this species.
ecology: In seasonal rain forests and lower montane rain forests on sandstone or limestone, 500–1,500 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (type: Santisuk 2694, holotype -BKF), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung).
ecology: Scattered on the limestone, ca 1,780–2,150 m alt. Hitherto only known from the type locality on Doi Chiang Dao, Chiang Mai. Recent botanical excursions have also recorded its existence on the limestone ridged top of Doi Tung in Chiang Rai.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Pae Poe).
distribution: Eastern Himalayas, from E Nepal, India [Assam, Sikkim (type), Manipur] to Bhutan and Myanmar (Bhamo, Myitkyina).
ecology: Uncommon on a stream slope in lower montane rain forests, ca 1,400 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Chang, Doi Khun Huai Pong), Nan (Doi Phukha); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Miang, Phu Kradueng).
ecology: Scattered by stream in lower and upper montane rain forests, 1,100–2,400 m alt. Flowering: November–January; fruiting: March–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Nan (type: Pooma et al. 1447, holotype -A, isotypes -BKF CMU).
distribution: Endemic to Doi Phu Kha National Park.
ecology: Scattered on steep slopes in shady ravines in lower montane rain forests, 1,100–1,700 m alt. Flowering: November; fruiting: February–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Chang, Doi Khun Huai Pong), Nan (Doi Phukha); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Miang, Phu Kradueng).
ecology: Scattered by stream in lower and upper montane rain forests, 1,100–2,400 m alt. Flowering: November–January; fruiting: March–July.

ecology: Scattered on steep slopes in shady ravines in lower montane rain forests, 1,100–1,700 m alt. Flowering: November; fruiting: February–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Pae Poe).
distribution: Eastern Himalayas, from E Nepal, India [Assam, Sikkim (type), Manipur] to Bhutan and Myanmar (Bhamo, Myitkyina).
ecology: Uncommon on a stream slope in lower montane rain forests, ca 1,400 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lamphun, Tak, Sukhothai, Kamphaeng Phet, Phichit, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Surin, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga.
distribution: Bangladhesh (type), Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, S Vietnam.
ecology: Deciduous and pine deciduous dipterocarp forests, to ca 1,300 m alt. Flowering: February–July; fruiting: March–December.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi, Phetchaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Trang, Satun, Songkhla, Yala.
distribution: Andaman Islands, Myanmar, Peninsular Malaysia (type), Borneo, Sumatra, the Philippines.
ecology: Evergreen forests, lowland to 700 m alt. Flowering: December–February; fruiting: March–August.

thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Rayong, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun (Tarutao), Yala, Narathiwat.

thailand: Widely cultivated throughout the country.
distribution: Although the exact origin is unknown, it is thought to have come from Africa, where it has been grown as a crop for centuries. Evidence suggests it was grown in Egypt as long ago as 2,000 BC. It is found in cultivation throughout the tropics.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Phru To Daeng).
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (type), northern Borneo, Sulawesi, New Guinea to the Caroline Islands.
ecology: The notes for the collection from Thailand only state “swamp forests by roadside”. In the rest of the range, however, the species is recorded as a climber in primary and disturbed habitats, including reaching the canopy of well drained and swampy forests, littoral forests and even mangrove, but also in forests regrowth and seaside scrub (see Sleumer, 1971: 91). No altitude data are given for the Thailand collection, but the species is recorded from sea level up to ca 300 m throughout the rest of its range.

thailand: Naturalised in Thailand: NORTHERN: Nakhon Sawan (Tham Phet Tham Thong Forest Park); EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani; CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Khao Samo Khon); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Ko Samet); based on the vernacular names also in NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Lamphun; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi
distribution: Native to Mexico, C America and the Caribbean, naturalised in S & SE Asia up to Australia and islands in the Pacific.
ecology: In tropical to subtropical areas, even semi-arid regions, usually in wastelands, but also along rivers and roads, in flood plains and cultivated fields, also found on limestone, seemingly preferring a dry season, sea level to 1,500 m alt. In Lop Buri reported from limestone. Flowering and fruiting: June–August. The fruits are distributed by animals as they attach to hoofs with their hooks and are therefore in English called Devil’s claw or Tiger’s claw. The species can become invasive and is, therefore, in most parts of Australia declared to be eradicated.

thailand: NORTHERN: Cultivated.

distribution: Myanmar, Andaman Islands, Cambodia, Vietnam, throughout Malesia to the Moluccas but probably absent from New Guinea (lectotype from Ambon, epitype from Sumatra).
ecology: In lowland evergreen rainforests, peat swamp forests, beach forests, occasionally in seasonal rainforests. The species does not seem to have any preferred host trees, plants either cling to tree trunks or grow on main crown branches of trees of various heights. Not infrequently forming large populations and often associated with other obligatory or facultative ant-plants such as the ant-fern

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat (Hala Bala).
distribution: Throughout Malesia from the Malay Peninsula to Australia and the Solomon Islands (type from Sumatra), also in Vietnam (Annam).
ecology: Growing below 500 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Trang (Khao Chong).
ecology: In evergreen forests, limestone hills, 100 m alt. Flowering: February.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Narathiwat.
ecology: In or at the edge of peat swamp forests or swamp, sometimes in coastal scrub or amongst patches of trees on sandy ground, sea level to ca 50 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Doi Pha Hom Pok), Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon NP), Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Doi Luang NP), Phitsanulok (Phu Miang, Phu Hin Rongkla NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Luang NP, Phu Kradueng NP, Phu Ruea NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao).
distribution: E Himalayas (Nepal – type) to upper Myanmar, SW China and N Vietnam.
ecology: Epiphytic on mossy tree trunks in dense evergreen forests, or (less commonly) on wet, mossy rocks in deep shade, sometimes also growing between rocks or in crevices in open, sun-exposed ridges (limestone, less often on sandstone or granite), 1,200–2,550 m alt. Flowering: July–September(–October); fruiting: (July–)September–February.
