thailand: NORTHERN: Nan (Tha Wang Pha), Tak (Raheng – lectotype of Morinda longifolia : Kerr 4577 -BK, isolectotypes -ABD BM K, designated by Chantaranothai 2019), Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Maha Sarakham (Kosum Phisai); EASTERN: Surin (Huai Thap Than), Si Sa Ket (Kantharom), Ubon Ratchathani (Kaeng Tana NP); CENTRAL: Lop Buri (Tha Wung), Suphan Buri, Ang Thong (Wat Klang), Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya (Sena), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok) (syntype of M. persicifolia var. oblonga : Schomburgk 191 -P); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao (Phanom Sarakham); PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Bangbao; Ban Na – lectotype of M. pandurifolia var. tenuifolia : Kerr 18124 -K [K000763792], isolectotypes -ABD BK BM K, designated by Chantaranothai 2019; Khian Sa), Phatthalung.
distribution: Bangladesh, Myanmar (type) to Indochina, China and Peninsular Malaysia.
ecology: In dry evergreen and deciduous dipterocarp forests, stream banks, 0−360 m alt. Flowering: December−April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon), Chiang Rai; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Bo Noi, Sai Yok, Sangkhla Buri – type: Kerr 10260, lectotype -K, isolectotypes -ABD BK BM KYO, designated by Chantaranothai 2019), Thong Phaphum, Thung Yai Naresuan WS).
ecology: In hill evergreen and mixed deciduous forests, 100−700 m alt. Flowering: January−March.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Bueng Kan (Pak Khat, Phon Phisai), Nakhon Phanom (Ban Theng), Khon Kaen (Nong Song Hong); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Ban Lat Yai), Nakhon Ratchasima (Non Sung, Phimai, Tha Chang), Surin (Samrong Thap), Si Sa Ket (Huai Thap Than, Kantharalak, Kanthararom), Ubon Ratchathani (Det Udom, Pha Sai, Phibun Mangsahan); SOUTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom (Tha Uthen), Maha Sarakham (Borabue).
ecology: In dry evergreen and deciduous dipterocarp forests, streamsides, 100−270 m alt. Flowering: January−June.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Sop Moei), Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Muang Aon, Doi Suthep-Pui NP, Mae Klang Falls), Nan, Lamphun (Mae Tha), Lampang (Khun Tan NP), Phrae (Song), Tak (Ban Tak); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Pak Pang – lectotype of Morinda pumila : Kerr 19981 -BK, isolectotypes -ABD BM K KYO, designated by Chantaranothai 2019), Nakhon Ratchasima (Pak Thong Chai, Wang Nam Khiao, Sakaerat), Si Sa Ket (Kanthararak); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Erawan NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Khao Khiao).
ecology: In dry evergreen and deciduous dipterocarp forests, 100−720 m alt. Flowering: February−May.

species_scientific_name: Adina trichotoma (Zoll. & Moritzi) Benth & Hook.f. ex B.D.Jacks.
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai (Tha Yaek – type of Adina polycephaloides : Winit 1860 -BK K), Nan, Lampang (Ban Ton – lectotype of A. parvula : Winit 675 -K, isolectotypes -BK BKF, designated by Ridsdale 1978); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong (La-un – type of A. polycephala var. noei : Noe [in Kerr] 16486 -BK K TCD), Nakhon Si Thammarat.
distribution: From E India and Bangladesh to upper and lower Myanmar and Indochina, south- and southeastwards to the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java, Borneo, the Philippines and New Guinea.
ecology: In evergreen forests (seasonal rain forests, occasionally lower montane rain forests) and (semi-)deciduous forests, up to 1,200 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Krabi (Lanta – type: Kerr 18977, lectotype -K, isolectotypes -BK SING, designated by Ridsdale 1978), Nakhon Si Thammarat, Songkhla.
ecology: Evergreen forests, mixed deciduous forests, beach forests, sometimes over limestone, 10–300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting all year round.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Lamphun, Lampang, Phrae, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Nong Bua Lum Phu, Mukdahan, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri,Chon Buri, Canthaburi; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani.
distribution: India (type), Sri Lanka eastwards to S China, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, also in northernmost Peninsular Malaysia (Perlis).
ecology: Mostly in deciduous vegetation (mixed deciduous forests decidous dipterocarp-oak forests, deciduous forests with bamboo), also over limestone, sometimes associated with seasonal rain forests, occasionally left as shade tree in between rice and cassava fields, 250–550 m alt. Flowering: January–July; fruiting: (July), September–February.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Yala, Narathiwat.
ecology: Very rare, lowland moist evergreen forests, 300–700 m alt. Flowering: September.

distribution: From India eastwards (type from Bangladesh) to Myanmar, Indochina, China, Taiwan.
ecology: In riverine vegetation, from sea level to 700 m alt.

species_scientific_name: Nauclea officinalis (Pierre ex Pit.) Merr. & Chun
thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang – lectotype of Nauclea brunnea : Kerr 15572 -BM, isolectotypes -BK K, designated by Seah & Wong 2019), Trang, Narathiwat.
distribution: SW China, Indochina (type from Cambodia), Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java, Borneo.
ecology: Scattered in evergreen forests, sometimes in wet to swampy places, 50–600(–800) m alt. Flowering: April; fruiting: May, September–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Phrae, Phitsanulok, Kamphaeng Phet, Phichit; NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN:Chaiyaphum, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi, Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok) (cultivated); SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Satun.
distribution: Sri Lanka (type), continental SE Asia (Bangladesh, Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam) throughout Malesia to N & NE Australia.
ecology: Scattered in mixed dipterocarp forests, mixed evergreen and deciduous forests, dry evergreen forests or in pine-dipterocarp forests with patches of dry evergreen forests, occasionally in lowland evergreen forests, often near streams (but not rheophytic), sometimes over limestone, also in disturbed, secondary forests, 50–850 m alt. Flowering: May–June; fruiting: June–November (old fruits often persisting until the following flowering period).

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: India (Assam), from Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra (type) to the Philippines and Sulawesi.
ecology: Lowland evergreen rain forests, frequently along watercourses, peat swamp forests and swampy places, to 200 m alt. Fruiting: May–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Lampang, Phrae, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima, Surin; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Phatthalung, Trang, Satun, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Sri Lanka, India. Bhutan to Indochina, throughout Malesia to New Guinea (Moluccas – type).
ecology: Frequently gregarious and most often growing as pioneer tree in open areas of (semi-)evergreen or mixed deciduous forests, not uncommonly by streams and rivers or in gullies and ravines in generally drier vegetation types, 50–1,500 m alt. Flowering: May–August(–November); fruiting: May–December.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Narathiwat.
ecology: Swamps and (peat) swamp forests, 0–75 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang (‘West coast and islands of Peninsular Siam, Tasan’ – type: White in Kloss 7053 -K [image]).
ecology: Lowland evergreen rainforests, in wet to damp places (sometimes along streams), in deep shade, 200–400 m alt.

ecology: Hill evergreen forests, mossy forests open place and secondary evergreen forests, 0–1,300 m alt. Flowering. June–November.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lamphun, Phrae, Kamphaeng Phet; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Khon Kaen, Sakon Nakhon, Mukdahan; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi, Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri; PENINSULAR: Chumphon.
distribution: In continental SE Asia from India to China, Cambodia and Vietnam, Taiwan, in Malesia from Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra (type) to New Guinea and Australia (Queensland).
ecology: Pine-oak forests, dry dipterocarp forests, open deciduous forests, seasonal rain forests, lower montane rain forests. Usually growing in undisturbed or disturbed open (grassy) areas on sandy to rocky ground, sometimes over limestone, 10–1,700 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: May–November (fruiting to January).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam); Chiang Mai (Mae Rim – type: Kerr 6249, holotype -K, isotypes -BK BM).
ecology: Open, grassy pine forests, 600–1,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–July; fruiting:–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lampang, Lamphun, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Ratchaburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri.
distribution: From India (type), Nepal to Indochina and S China.
ecology: Dry dipterocarp forests, mixed deciduous forests, pine savannas. Usually growing in open, sometimes disturbed, grassy areas, on clayey soil and also over limestone, occasionally in marshy, water-logged areas, 400–1,200 m alt. Flowering: (March) May–September; fruiting: July–October.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam); Chiang Mai (Mae Rim – type: Kerr 6249, holotype -K, isotypes -BK BM).

ecology: Pine-oak forests, dry dipterocarp forests, open deciduous forests, seasonal rain forests, lower montane rain forests. Usually growing in undisturbed or disturbed open (grassy) areas on sandy to rocky ground, sometimes over limestone, 10–1,700 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: May–November (fruiting to January).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Doi Lan, Mae On); Nan (Tham Sakoen, Song Khwae, Bo Kluea, Doi Phu Kha); Lampang (Doi Khun Tan).

ecology: Open places, rice fields, swampy areas, 0–1,700 m alt. Flowering throughout the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Mae Salong, Ban San Pa Sak), Chiang Rai (Ban Wiang Song, Thoeng, Mae Sai); NORTH-EASTERN: Kalasin (Yang Tlat); EASTERN: Si Saket (Hua Kua, Tham Yae, Phayu), Ubon Ratchathani (Ban Kut Riang Mun, Nam Yuen); CENTRAL: Ang Thong (Wat Klang), Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Phangnga (Ko Talibong).
distribution: Tropical and subtropical Asia from India, Nepal to the Philippines and China (type from India Orientalis).
ecology: Open places, rice fields, swampy areas, 250–1,100 m alt. Flowering throughout the year.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Wang Chao); Nakhon Sawan (Kaeng Ap Nang); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP); EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani (Phu Chong Na Yoi NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Ban Ta Ruang – type: Kerr 9720 -BK BM K).
ecology: Dry deciduous forests, sandstone, 200–600 m alt. Flowering: August–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mapha), Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Kerr 821 -BM K TCD, Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Wachirathan Falls, Chom Thong, Om Koi), Chiang Rai (Doi Luang NP, Khun Chae NP), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan NP), Lampang (Hang Chat, Chae Son NP), Tak (Doi Kha), Kamphaeng Phet (Mae Wong NP, Khlong Lan NP).
ecology: Dry evergreen forests, pine-oak forests, deciduous forests, 350– 1,400 m alt. Flowering: July–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Phu Hin Rong Kla); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng, Phu Luang), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP), Nakhon Phanom (Phu Langka), Kalasin (Yang Tlat), Khon Kaen (Khao Saun Kwang, Phu Ra-ngum); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Ban Non Ta Ten, Non Deang), Si Sa Ket (Kantalarak, Phanom Dongrak WS), Ubon Ratchathani (Khong Chiam, Pa Dong Na Tham, Pha Taem NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo (Wattana Nakhon – type of Oldenlandia gracilipes var. longicalyx : Put 1926 -BK K TCD), Chanthaburi (Leam Sadet, Khung Kraben).
ecology: Open places, sandstone bed rock, sandy soil, 0–300 m alt. Flowering: August–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Rim), Lampang, Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng NP, Sithan), Sakon Nakhon (Phu Phan NP), Maha Sarakham (Pa Khok Dong Khaeng), Khon Kaen (Khao Saun Kwang); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Dan Khun Tot), Buri Ram, Surin (Sangkha), Ubon Ratchathani (Bunthafrik, Soi Sawan Falls, Khong Chiam); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Salak Phra WS), Prachuap Khiri Khan (Sam Roi Yot NP); SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong, Chanthaburi (Khung Kraben, Laem Sadet); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Muaeng Len, Kapoe), Surat Thani (Bang Bao), Songkhla (Hat Yai, Khlong Hoi Khong).
distribution: India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar (syntype), China, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malay Peninsula (Penang syntype), Sumatra, Java, Borneo.
ecology: Dry deciduous forests, open places, grass fields, seashores, sandy soil, 0–600 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

species_scientific_name: Scleromitrion scabrum (Wall. ex Kurz) Neupane & N.Wikstr.
thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Chan), Nan (Doi Phu Kha NP), Lamphun (Doi Khun Tan), Uttaradit (Phu Soi Dao), Tak (Khao Pha Wo), Phitsanulok (Thung Salang Luang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Luang WS), Bueng Kan (Phu Wua WS), Nakhon Phanom (Phu Langka); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Ban Nam Phrom), Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai NP); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Thong Pha Phum NP).
ecology: Dry evergreen and deciduous forests, shaded, 200–1,500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep-Pui); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Route from Dan Sai to Phu Ruea); EASTERN: Buri Ram (Huai Thalaeng, Hin Dat), Ubon Ratchathani (Ban Bahai Village); PENINSULAR: Chumphon, (Kanthachai, Bang Son), Ranong (Khao Ya, Laem Son NP, Kapoe), Surat Thani (Kanchanadit), Phatthalung (Sak), Trang (Khao Chong, Hat Chao Mai NP, Si Kao, Thung Kha), Satun (Thung Ya Wangphra, Khuan Don).
distribution: Laos, Sumatra, Java, Borneo (Kalimantan – type), New Guinea, Australia.
ecology: Open places, rice fields, swampy areas, 0–600 m alt. Flowering and fruiting throughout the year.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Khao Niphan Temple, Wiang Sa), Trang (Wat Tham Iso), Satun (Mu Ko Phetra NP, La Ngu), Songkhla (Khao Rup Chang, Padang Besar, Sadao).
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Indonesia (type from Java)(see Note).
ecology: Limestone hills, 0–200 m alt. Flowering: January–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Ma Pha, San Ban Dan WS), Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Inthanon, Doi Pha Hom Pok, Mae Pan Falls), Chiang Rai, Nan (Doi Phu Kha), Lampang (Doi Khun Tan NP, Hang Chat), Uttaradit (Phu Soi Dao), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang NP); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng), Nakhon Phanom (Phu Langka NP); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Nam Phrom); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Ban Kao); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga ( type of Hedyotis hirta : Haniff & Nur SF 3871 -K SING).
distribution: India, Bhutan, Nepal, Bangladesh, S China, Myanmar, Laos Vietnam, Cambodia, Malay Peninsula including Singapore, Indonesia (Amboina, Java – type), the Philippines, S China.
ecology: Evergreen forests, deciduous forests, open places or shaded areas, 50–1,400 m alt. Flowering: August–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phayao, Lamphun, Lampang, Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Nakhon Ratchasima; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Phuket, Songkhla, Satun. (see Note 1).
distribution: A pantropical weed originally from tropical America (Jamaica – type), introduced to tropical Africa, Asia and Australia.
ecology: In roadside vegetation, in open, disturbed places in forests and woodland, sea level to over 1,000 m alt. Flowering: May–December; fruiting: October–January.

species_scientific_name: Spermacoce exilis (L.O.Williams) C.D.Adams ex W.C.Burger & C.M.Taylor
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Tropical America from Mexico to Paraguay (Costa Rica – type), naturalized throughout the Old World tropics.
ecology: Slightly wetter parts of open disturbed areas, in plantations, also on margin of streams and margin of peat swamp forests, over granite, phyllite or limestone, sea level to 1,550 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Si Saket; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Pattani.
distribution: Tropical and subtropical America (S America to Paraguay, type from Jamaica), naturalized throughout tropics of Africa, Asia and Oceania.
ecology: Open disturbed areas, roadsides, found over sandstone, sea level to 1,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–October.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Petchaburi; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok).
distribution: Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia (type from Java), the Philippines, New Guinea, adventive in tropical Africa and the Americas.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Payao, Lampang, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Udon Thani; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Trang, Songkhla, Yala.
distribution: Tropical America (Mexico to Paraguay, type from the Dominican Republic); naturalized throughout tropics of Africa, Asia and Oceania.
ecology: Open disturbed areas (e.g., roadsides, clearings in forests), found over sandstone, 100–1,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lamphun, Lampang, Tak, Sukhothai, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Suphan Buri; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Songkhla
distribution: Indian subcontinent (type from Nepal), Myanmar, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, the Philippines, China, Taiwan, introduced in tropical Africa.
ecology: Usually occurs in open deciduous dipterocarp forests, degraded pine-oak forests, over granite, shale or sandstone, 130–1,400 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–December.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Tak, Phitsanulok; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachinburi, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga, Songkhla, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Tropical America (Mexico to Paraguay, type from French Guiana); naturalized throughout the tropics of Africa, Asia and Oceania.
ecology: Common in wetter parts of open disturbed areas, plantations, but also collected from open mixed deciduous and dry evergreen forests, sea level to 1,500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Suphan Buri, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chachoengsao, Chon Buri, Trat; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phangna, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Satun, Songkhla, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Indigenous to tropical and subtropical Asia (presumably from India to Malesia and China, type from Sri Lanka) and Australia; naturalized in Africa, parts of Asia and Oceania, but see note below.
ecology: Open disturbed areas and dry forests, usually on sand, often at the beaches, sea level to 500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: (June–)August–December.

ecology: Slightly wetter parts of open disturbed areas, in plantations, also on margin of streams and margin of peat swamp forests, over granite, phyllite or limestone, sea level to 1,550 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–January.

distribution: Tropical America (Mexico to Paraguay, type from French Guiana); naturalized throughout the tropics of Africa, Asia and Oceania.
ecology: Common in wetter parts of open disturbed areas, plantations, but also collected from open mixed deciduous and dry evergreen forests, sea level to 1,500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–January.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Petchaburi; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok).
distribution: Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia (type from Java), the Philippines, New Guinea, adventive in tropical Africa and the Americas.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lamphun, Lampang, Tak, Sukhothai, Phitsanulok, Nakhon Sawan; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon, Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani, Kanchanaburi, Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Suphan Buri; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri, Rayong; PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Songkhla
distribution: Indian subcontinent (type from Nepal), Myanmar, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, the Philippines, China, Taiwan, introduced in tropical Africa.
ecology: Usually occurs in open deciduous dipterocarp forests, degraded pine-oak forests, over granite, shale or sandstone, 130–1,400 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August–December.

distribution: Tropical America (Mexico to Paraguay, type from the Dominican Republic); naturalized throughout tropics of Africa, Asia and Oceania.
ecology: Open disturbed areas (e.g., roadsides, clearings in forests), found over sandstone, 100–1,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: June–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Si Saket; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Pattani.
distribution: Tropical and subtropical America (S America to Paraguay, type from Jamaica), naturalized throughout tropics of Africa, Asia and Oceania.
ecology: Open disturbed areas, roadsides, found over sandstone, sea level to 1,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–October.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani (Bukit – type: Kerr 7114, holotype -K, isotypes -A [image] BKF L [image] U [image]), Narathiwat (Hala-Bala WS).
ecology: Evergreen forests, 100–150 m alt. Flowering: June–July; fruiting: July onwards.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan, Phrae (Ban Nam Klai – type: Larsen et al. 44379, holotype -AAU, isotypes -BKF C HAN K L P PSU SING W); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao NP), Loei (Phu Luang WS); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum, Ubon Ratchathani.
ecology: In seasonal rain forests and lower montane rain forests, often in damp to wet places along streams, in areas of deciduous forests usually in evergreen gallery forests bordering streams, 400–1,400 m alt. Fowering and fruiting: November–April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Angka, Doi Chiang Dao).
distribution: Afghanistan, Himalayas, Pakistan, India, Nepal (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, China, Sumatra.
ecology: In open grassy ground in the upper montane zone or at edge of upper montane rain forests, 2,100–2,550 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type of Galium petiolatum : Kerr 6577, holotype -K, isotype -BK), Nan (Doi Phukha NP).
distribution: From Pakistan and India through the Himalayas (Bhutan, Nepal) eastwards to upper Myanmar (type of
ecology: In open rocky ground, on rocky ridges, in crevices, occasionally in the undergrowth of montane scrub, appears to be confined to limestone, (1,000–)1,800–2,250 m alt. Flowering: July–November; fruiting: September–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Angka, Doi Chiang Dao).
distribution: Afghanistan, Himalayas, Pakistan, India, Nepal (type), Bangladesh, Myanmar, China, Sumatra.
ecology: In open grassy ground in the upper montane zone or at edge of upper montane rain forests, 2,100–2,550 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type of Galium petiolatum : Kerr 6577, holotype -K, isotype -BK), Nan (Doi Phukha NP).
distribution: From Pakistan and India through the Himalayas (Bhutan, Nepal) eastwards to upper Myanmar (type of
ecology: In open rocky ground, on rocky ridges, in crevices, occasionally in the undergrowth of montane scrub, appears to be confined to limestone, (1,000–)1,800–2,250 m alt. Flowering: July–November; fruiting: September–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Kerr 1832 -K); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao), Loei (Na Haeo, Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Phu Khiao WS).
ecology: Mostly in open places or at the edge of hill evergreen forests, sometimes along streams in evergreen vegetation, 600–1,350 m alt. Flowering: February–May.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Angka – type: Garrett 325, holotype -K, isotypes -E L).
ecology: At the edge of upper montane rain forests, 2,450–2,550 m alt. Flowering: April–August; fruiting: July–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Ang Khang), Nan (Doi Phukha NP).
ecology: Often associated with limestone rocks and cliffs in mixed evergreen and deciduous forests, growing in cracks, in open spots or at the edge of lower montane forests, 1,100–2,100 m alt. Flowering: (July) September–December; fruiting: October–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai.
ecology: In mixed deciduous forests withDipterocarpus obtusifolius, in open grassy deciduous forests or in open pine forests, mostly growing in poor sandy soil, 1,000–1,300 m alt. Flowering: June–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Doi Ang Khang), Nan (Doi Phukha NP).
ecology: Often associated with limestone rocks and cliffs in mixed evergreen and deciduous forests, growing in cracks, in open spots or at the edge of lower montane forests, 1,100–2,100 m alt. Flowering: (July) September–December; fruiting: October–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Inthanon, Angka – type: Garrett 325, holotype -K, isotypes -E L).
ecology: At the edge of upper montane rain forests, 2,450–2,550 m alt. Flowering: April–August; fruiting: July–January.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai.
ecology: In mixed deciduous forests withDipterocarpus obtusifolius, in open grassy deciduous forests or in open pine forests, mostly growing in poor sandy soil, 1,000–1,300 m alt. Flowering: June–July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type: Kerr 1832 -K); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Nam Nao), Loei (Na Haeo, Phu Kradueng); EASTERN: Chaiyaphum (Phu Khiao WS).
ecology: Mostly in open places or at the edge of hill evergreen forests, sometimes along streams in evergreen vegetation, 600–1,350 m alt. Flowering: February–May.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Phuket, Satun.
distribution: S India (type), Sri Lanka, Andaman Islands.
ecology: Confined to sandy beaches and usually growing in large colonies, at sea level.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot), Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Chanthaburi, Trat; CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP); PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Trang, Phangnga, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang), Satun.
distribution: Widespread in tropical Africa including Madagascar, N to S America (type from Jamica) and Asia from Sri Lanka, S India through China to Indochina, Malesia to New Guinea, NE Australia and the Pacific Islands (see Note).
ecology: Open or shaded, damp places in evergreen or partly deciduous forests, also as weed in plantations, 0–1,100 m alt.

thailand: Trang, Krabi (Khao Phanom).
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Borneo, Java (type), New Guinea.
ecology: Evergreen forests, 100–500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: March, April.

thailand: NORTHERN: Tak (Doi Hua Mot), Phitsanulok; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Chanthaburi, Trat; CENTRAL: Saraburi (Muak Lek); SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan NP); PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Trang, Phangnga, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang), Satun.
distribution: Widespread in tropical Africa including Madagascar, N to S America (type from Jamica) and Asia from Sri Lanka, S India through China to Indochina, Malesia to New Guinea, NE Australia and the Pacific Islands (see Note).
ecology: Open or shaded, damp places in evergreen or partly deciduous forests, also as weed in plantations, 0–1,100 m alt.

thailand: Trang, Krabi (Khao Phanom).
distribution: Malay Peninsula, Borneo, Java (type), New Guinea.
ecology: Evergreen forests, 100–500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: March, April.

thailand: Probably occuring in Peninsular Thailand.
distribution: Widely distributed from New Zealand, Australia to N, C & S America, Pacific Islands (Hawaii), Malesia, China, Taiwan, Veitnam.
ecology: Hillsides at middle altitudes.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
distribution: India (lectotype), Nepal, Sri Lanka to China, Taiwan, throughout Malesia, to Australia and Oceania, adventive in N America (United States, Mexico)and Mauritius.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen; EASTERN: Ubon Ratchathani; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (see Note)
distribution: Tropical America (Brazil – type); naturalized in tropical Africa, continental SE & E Asia, Sri Lanka, Malesia and the Pacific region.
ecology: Roadsides, edge of plantations, disturbed areas along streams, over limestone or sandstone bedrock, 100–200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: January, May, August, September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Nan, Lampang, Tak; PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Thung Song, Khao Chaem – type of Clarkella siamensis : Rabil 139, holotype -K, isotypes -BK BM).
distribution: As for genus (India, Uttar Pradesh – type).
ecology: In shaded, moist to wet limestone outcrops or cliffs, growing in cracks of rocks, often associated with various Gesneriaceae, 450–1,100 m alt. Flowering and fruiting in the rainy season (July–September).

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai, Nan, Phrae, Lampang, Tak, Phitsanulok; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Bo Rae – type lectotype of Argostemma saxicolum : Put 217 -K, isolectotype -BK, designated by Sridith 1999); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Nang Rong Falls).
ecology: On moist to wet, often mossy rocks in evergreen forests, confined to limestone, 100–900 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Khlong Ton – type: Kerr 14440, holotype -K, isotypes -BK BM); Yala.
ecology: On moist rocks by streams in evergreen forests, 200–1,050 m alt. Flowering: March; fruiting: June.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
distribution: Laos, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra. In Thailand only subsp.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala (Betong).
ecology: On moist rocks in evergreen forests, 200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: August.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala, Narathiwat.
ecology: On moist rocks in evergreen forests, 950–1,050 m alt. Flowering: February–June; fruiting: October.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga.
ecology: On moist rocks near streams or in wet places in evergreen rain forests, 0–400 m alt. Flowering: March–May; fruiting: May.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Krabi (Phanom Bencha – type: Kerr 18720, holo/lectotype -K, isolectotypes -BK BM; lectotype of Argostemma septatum var. flaccidum : Kerr 18687, isolectotypes -BK BM, designated by Sridith 1999 K), Pattani (Khao Kalakhiri – type: holo/lectotype of A. septatum var. minus : Kerr 14958 -K, isotypes -BK BM), Trang (Khao Sung – holo/lectotype of A. septatum : Kerr 15261 -K, isotypes -BK BM SING), Yala.
ecology: On moist rocks in evergreen forests, 700–1,300 m alt. Flowering: March– April; fruiting: April–May.

ecology: In full sun on sandstone plateaux at ca 1,200 m among small trees, bushes, ferns, mosses and grasses. Growing in spongy, accumulated leaf litter and moss with thin, sandy soil derived from the bedrock. Growth from May–October. Flowering: July–September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga (type of Boesenbergia ochroleuca : Illustration no. 00764, lectotype -SING; type of B. acuminata : Shimizu et al. T7917, holotype -KYO, isotype -AAU).
ecology: Grows on limestone outcrops near the sea. Plants occur in full sun or light shade among small shrubs and trees. Individual plants occur in any crevice or surface where there is an accumulation of organic matter. New plant generation is via seed and brood tubers. Regeneration is via stem tubers.
